In [ ]:
# regular expression
# Imagine you have a string object s. Now suppose you need to write Python code to find out whether s contains the substring '123'. There are at least a couple ways to do this. You could use the in operator If you want to know not only whether '123' exists in s but also where it exists, then you can use .find() or .index(). Each of these returns the character position within s where the substring resides
In [1]:
s = 'foo123bar'
print ('123' in s)

True
In [2]:
s.find('123')
Out[2]:
3
In [3]:
s.index('123')
Out[3]:
3
In [11]:
def return_all_syntax(string, sub_str):
    total_index  = list()
    for each in string :
        if each in sub_str:
            total_index.append(string.index(each))
    return total_index

return_all_syntax('foo123bar123','123')
Out[11]:
[3, 4, 5, 3, 4, 5]

In these examples, the matching is done by a straightforward character-by-character comparison. That will get the job done in many cases. But sometimes, the problem is more complicated than that. For example, rather than searching for a fixed substring like '123', suppose you wanted to determine whether a string contains any three consecutive decimal digit characters, as in the strings 'foo123bar', 'foo456bar', '234baz', and 'qux678'.

Strict character comparisons won’t cut it here. This is where regexes in Python come to the rescue.

In [16]:
#####
import re
In [15]:
re
Out[15]:
<module 're' from '/opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.8/re.py'>
In [17]:
s = 'foo123bar'
In [18]:
re.search('123', s)
Out[18]:
<re.Match object; span=(3, 6), match='123'>
In [25]:
res = re.search('123','foo123bar123')
print(res)

<re.Match object; span=(3, 6), match='123'>
In [27]:
if re.search('123', s):
    print('Found a match.')
else:
    print('No match.')

Found a match.
In [29]:
s[3:6]
Out[29]:
'123'

In this example, the match starts at character position 3 and extends up to but not including position 6.

match='123' indicates which characters from matched.

This is a good start. But in this case, the pattern is just the plain string '123'. The pattern matching here is still just character-by-character comparison, pretty much the same as the in operator and .find() examples shown earlier. The match object helpfully tells you that the matching characters were '123', but that’s not much of a revelation since those were exactly the characters you searched for.

In [30]:
##########

Python Regex Metacharacters

The real power of regex matching in Python emerges when contains special characters called metacharacters. These have a unique meaning to the regex matching engine and vastly enhance the capability of the search.

In [32]:
s
Out[32]:
'foo123bar'
In [33]:
re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9]', s)
Out[33]:
<re.Match object; span=(3, 6), match='123'>
In [34]:
res = re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9]', s)
In [36]:
res = re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9][0-9]', s)
print(res)

None
In [44]:
res = re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9]', '1234kamal456')
print(res)

<re.Match object; span=(0, 3), match='123'>
In [ ]:
In [35]:
Out[35]:
'123'
In [50]:
re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9]', 'fooghg456bar')
# print ('fooghg456bar'[6:9])
Out[50]:
<re.Match object; span=(6, 9), match='456'>
In [51]:
re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9]', '234baz')
Out[51]:
<re.Match object; span=(0, 3), match='234'>
In [55]:
re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9]', '23b4az')
In [56]:
re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9]', '237b4az')
Out[56]:
<re.Match object; span=(0, 3), match='237'>
In [63]:
re.search('[0-9][0-9][0-9]', 'qux678')
Out[63]:
<re.Match object; span=(3, 6), match='678'>
In [67]:
re.search('[0-9][0-9]', 'qu6x78')
Out[67]:
<re.Match object; span=(4, 6), match='78'>
In [65]:
'qu6x78'[4:6]
Out[65]:
'78'

On the other hand, a string that doesn’t contain three consecutive digits won’t match:

In [ ]:

With regexes in Python, you can identify patterns in a string that you wouldn’t be able to find with the in operator or with string methods.

Take a look at another regex metacharacter. The dot (.) metacharacter matches any character except a newline, so it functions like a wildcard:

In [68]:
s
Out[68]:
'foo123bar'
In [69]:
re.search('1.3', s)
Out[69]:
<re.Match object; span=(3, 6), match='123'>
In [82]:
re.search('1...3','1ka83')
Out[82]:
<re.Match object; span=(0, 5), match='1ka83'>
In [71]:
re.search('1.3','1q3')
print('1q3'[0:3])

1q3
In [75]:
re.search('1.3.5','1a3b5')
print('1a3b5'[0:5])

1a3b5
In [78]:
re.search('1.3.5','19375')
print('19375'[0:5])

19375
In [83]:
print(re.search('1.3', s))

<re.Match object; span=(3, 6), match='123'>
In [87]:
re.search('1.3','foo13bar')

In the first example, the regex 1.3 matches '123' because the '1' and '3' match literally, and the . matches the '2'. Here, you’re essentially asking, “Does s contain a '1', then any character (except a newline), then a '3'?” The answer is yes for 'foo123bar' but no for 'foo13bar'.

Character(s) Meaning . Matches any single character except newline ^ ∙ Anchors a match at the start of a string ∙ Complements a character class $ Anchors a match at the end of a string * Matches zero or more repetitions + Matches one or more repetitions ? ∙ Matches zero or one repetition ∙ Specifies the non-greedy versions of *, +, and ? ∙ Introduces a lookahead or lookbehind assertion ∙ Creates a named group {} Matches an explicitly specified number of repetitions \ ∙ Escapes a metacharacter of its special meaning ∙ Introduces a special character class ∙ Introduces a grouping backreference [] Specifies a character class | Designates alternation () Creates a group : # = ! Designate a specialized group <> Creates a named group

skipped regex¶

In [90]:
# *args & **kwargs
In [95]:
def add_all(a,b,c):
    return a+b+c
add_all(2,3,5)
Out[95]:
10
In [98]:
def add_all(*args):
    return sum(args)
add_all(1,2)
add_all(1,5,6,7,8,9,0)
Out[98]:
36
In [103]:
def return_String(*args):
    return ''.join(args)
return_String('l','e','t','s',' ','u','p','g','r','a','d','e')
Out[103]:
'lets upgrade'
In [113]:
def return_given_indexes(*args,start=2,end=7):
    return args[start:end]
return_given_indexes(1,2,3,4,5,1,4,6,7,8,5,4,2,8)
Out[113]:
(3, 4, 5, 1, 4)
In [125]:
def items_from_market(**kwargs):
    return kwargs.items()
items_from_market(tomato='5kg',banana=12,change =23.5,waste = [1,2,3,4],\
                 came =True,more ={'place':'Mumbai'})
Out[125]:
dict_items([('tomato', '5kg'), ('banana', 12), ('change', 23.5), ('waste', [1, 2, 3, 4]), ('came', True), ('more', {'place': 'Mumbai'})])
In [126]:

srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1235" data-file-height="650" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a><br />\n<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Flag_of_Hawaii.svg/23px-Flag_of_Hawaii.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Flag_of_Hawaii.svg/35px-Flag_of_Hawaii.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Flag_of_Hawaii.svg/46px-Flag_of_Hawaii.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a></li></ul>\n</td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" class="infobox-header" style="color: black; background-color: pink;">Language codes</th></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/ISO_639-2" title="ISO 639-2">ISO 639-2</a></span></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><code><span class="plainlinks"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/php/langcodes_name.php?code_ID=183">haw</a></span></code></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/ISO_639-3" title="ISO 639-3">ISO 639-3</a></span></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><code><a href="https://iso639-3.sil.org/code/haw" class="extiw" title="iso639-3:haw">haw</a></code></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><a href="/wiki/Glottolog" title="Glottolog">Glottolog</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><code><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://glottolog.org/resource/languoid/id/hawa1245">hawa1245</a></code></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><a href="/wiki/Endangered_Languages_Project" title="Endangered Languages Project">ELP</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.endangeredlanguages.com/lang/125">Hawaiian</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><a href="/wiki/Linguasphere_Observatory" title="Linguasphere Observatory">Linguasphere</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><code>39-CAQ-e</code></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-below noprint selfref" style="background-color:#E7E7FF;padding:0.3em 0.5em;text-align:left;line-height:1.3;"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">IPA</a> phonetic symbols.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA#Rendering_issues" title="Help:IPA">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a> instead of <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> characters. For an introductory guide on IPA symbols, see <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">Help:IPA</a>.</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p><b>Hawaiian</b> (<i><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">&#x2bb;Ōlelo Hawai&#x2bb;i</i></i>, <small>pronounced&#160;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Hawaiian" title="Help:IPA/Hawaiian">[ʔoːˈlɛlo həˈvɐjʔi]</a></span>)<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Polynesian language">Polynesian language</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_language_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Austronesian language family">Austronesian language family</a> that takes its name from <a href="/wiki/Hawaii_(island)" title="Hawaii (island)">Hawai&#x2bb;i</a>, the largest island in the tropical North Pacific <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> where it developed. Hawaiian, along with <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, is an official language of the <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">US state of Hawaii</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Article_XV,_Section_4_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Article_XV,_Section_4-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kamehameha_III" title="Kamehameha III">King Kamehameha III</a> established the first Hawaiian-language <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">constitution</a> in 1839 and 1840.\n</p><p>For various reasons, including <a href="/wiki/Hawaii_Territory" class="mw-redirect" title="Hawaii Territory">territorial</a> legislation establishing English as the official language in schools, the number of <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">native speakers</a> of Hawaiian gradually decreased during the period from the 1830s to the 1950s. Hawaiian was essentially displaced by English on six of seven inhabited islands. In 2001, native speakers of Hawaiian amounted to less than 0.1% of the statewide population. Linguists were unsure if Hawaiian and other <a href="/wiki/Endangered_language" title="Endangered language">endangered languages</a> would survive.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="Source does not mention linguists or Hawaiian language (January 2020)">failed verification</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>Nevertheless, from around 1949 to the present day, there has been a gradual increase in attention to and promotion of the language. Public Hawaiian-language immersion preschools called <a href="/wiki/P%C5%ABnana_Leo" title="Pūnana Leo">Pūnana Leo</a> were established in 1984; other immersion schools followed soon after that. The first students to start in immersion preschool have now graduated from college and many are fluent Hawaiian speakers. The federal government has acknowledged this development. For example, the Hawaiian National Park Language Correction Act of 2000 changed the names of several <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national parks</a> in Hawai&#x2bb;i, observing the Hawaiian spelling.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> However, the language is still classified as critically endangered by UNESCO.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Creole_language" title="Creole language">creole language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Pidgin" title="Hawaiian Pidgin">Hawaiian Pidgin</a> (or Hawaii Creole English, HCE), is more commonly spoken in Hawai&#x2bb;i than Hawaiian. Some linguists, as well as many locals, argue that Hawaiian Pidgin is a <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">dialect</a> of American English.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Born from the increase of immigrants from Japan, China, Puerto Rico, Korea, Portugal, Spain and the Philippines, the pidgin creole language was a necessity in the plantations. Hawaiian and immigrant laborers as well as the white <i>luna,</i> or overseers, found a way to communicate amongst themselves. Pidgin eventually made its way off the plantation and into the greater community, where it is still used to this day.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_alphabet" title="Hawaiian alphabet">Hawaiian alphabet</a> has 13 letters: five vowels: a e i o u (each with a long pronunciation and a short one) and eight consonants: he ke la mu nu pi we, including a glottal stop called <a href="#Glottal_stop">&#x2bb;okina</a>.\n</p>\n<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a class="toctext">Family and origin</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Methods_of_proving_Hawaiian&#39;s_linguistic_relationships"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Methods of proving Hawaiian\'s linguistic relationships</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Mutual_intelligibility"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Mutual intelligibility</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#History"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#First_European_contact"><span class="tocnumber">3.1</span> <span class="toctext">First European contact</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-7"><a href="#Folk_tales"><span class="tocnumber">3.1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Folk tales</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8"><a href="#Written_Hawaiian"><span class="tocnumber">3.2</span> <span class="toctext">Written Hawaiian</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-9"><a href="#Suppression_of_Hawaiian"><span class="tocnumber">3.3</span> <span class="toctext">Suppression of Hawaiian</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-10"><a href="#1949_to_present"><span class="tocnumber">3.4</span> <span class="toctext">1949 to present</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-11"><a href="#Niʻihau"><span class="tocnumber">3.5</span> <span class="toctext">Niʻihau</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#Hawaiian_in_schools"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Hawaiian in schools</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-13"><a href="#Hawaiian_medium_schools"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Hawaiian medium schools</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-14"><a href="#Higher_education"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">Higher education</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-15"><a href="#Orthography"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Orthography</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-16"><a href="#Origin"><span class="tocnumber">5.1</span> <span class="toctext">Origin</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-17"><a href="#Glottal_stop"><span class="tocnumber">5.2</span> <span class="toctext">Glottal stop</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-18"><a href="#History_2"><span class="tocnumber">5.2.1</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-19"><a href="#Electronic_encoding"><span class="tocnumber">5.2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Electronic encoding</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Macron"><span class="tocnumber">5.3</span> <span class="toctext">Macron</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-21"><a href="#Pronunciation"><span class="tocnumber">5.4</span> <span class="toctext">Pronunciation</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-22"><a href="#Phonology"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Phonology</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-23"><a href="#Consonants"><span class="tocnumber">6.1</span> <span class="toctext">Consonants</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-24"><a href="#Vowels"><span class="tocnumber">6.2</span> <span class="toctext">Vowels</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-25"><a href="#Monophthongs"><span class="tocnumber">6.2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Monophthongs</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-26"><a href="#Diphthongs"><span class="tocnumber">6.2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Diphthongs</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-27"><a href="#Phonotactics"><span class="tocnumber">6.3</span> <span class="toctext">Phonotactics</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-28"><a href="#Historical_development"><span class="tocnumber">6.4</span> <span class="toctext">Historical development</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-29"><a href="#Grammar"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Grammar</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-30"><a href="#Semantic_domains"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Semantic domains</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-31"><a href="#Varieties_and_debates"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Varieties and debates</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-32"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-33"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-34"><a href="#References_2"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-35"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Name">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>The Hawaiian language takes its name from the largest island in the Hawaiian state, <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a> (<i><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">Hawai&#x2bb;i</i></i> in the Hawaiian language). The island name was first written in English in 1778 by British explorer <a href="/wiki/James_Cook" title="James Cook">James Cook</a> and his crew members. They wrote it as "Owhyhee" or "Owhyee". It is written "Oh-Why-hee" on the first map of Sandwich Islands engraved by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tobias_Conrad_Lotter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tobias Conrad Lotter (page does not exist)">Tobias Conrad Lotter</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;&#91;<a href="https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobias_Conrad_Lotter" class="extiw" title="de:Tobias Conrad Lotter">de</a>&#93;</span> in 1781.<sup id="cite_ref-Princeton_Library_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Princeton_Library-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Explorers Mortimer (1791) and <a href="/wiki/Otto_von_Kotzebue" title="Otto von Kotzebue">Otto von Kotzebue</a> (1821) used that spelling.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The initial "O" in the name is a reflection of the fact that Hawaiian predicates unique identity by using a <a href="/wiki/Copula_(linguistics)" title="Copula (linguistics)">copula</a> form, <i>o</i>, immediately before a proper noun.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> Thus, in Hawaiian, the name of the island is expressed by saying <i><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">O Hawai&#x2bb;i</i></i>, which means "[This] is Hawai&#x2bb;i."<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> The Cook expedition also wrote "Otaheite" rather than "Tahiti."<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The spelling "why" in the name reflects the <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[hw]</span> pronunciation of <i>wh</i> in 18th-century English (still <a href="/wiki/Pronunciation_of_English_%E2%9F%A8wh%E2%9F%A9" title="Pronunciation of English ⟨wh⟩">used</a> in parts of the <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">English-speaking world</a>). <i>Why</i> was pronounced <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[hwai]</span>. The spelling "hee" or "ee" in the name represents the sounds <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[hi]</span>, or <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[i]</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Putting the parts together, <i>O-why-(h)ee</i> reflects <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[o-hwai-i]</span>, a reasonable approximation of the native pronunciation, <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[o hɐwɐiʔi]</span>.\n</p><p>American missionaries bound for Hawai&#x2bb;i used the phrases "Owhihe Language" and "Owhyhee language" in Boston prior to their departure in October 1819 and during their five-month voyage to Hawai&#x2bb;i.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> They still used such phrases as late as March 1822.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> However, by July 1823, they had begun using the phrase "Hawaiian Language."<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In Hawaiian, the language is called <i><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">&#x2bb;Ōlelo Hawai&#x2bb;i</i></i>, since adjectives follow nouns.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family_and_origin">Family and origin</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Family and origin">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>Hawaiian is a Polynesian member of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian language family</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> It is closely related to other <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_languages" title="Polynesian languages">Polynesian languages</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Samoan_language" title="Samoan language">Samoan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marquesan_language" title="Marquesan language">Marquesan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tahitian_language" title="Tahitian language">Tahitian</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language" title="Māori language">Māori</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rapa_Nui_language" title="Rapa Nui language">Rapa Nui</a> (the language of <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Tongan_language" title="Tongan language">Tongan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>\nAccording to Schütz (1994), the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Marquesas_Islands" title="Culture of the Marquesas Islands">Marquesans</a> colonized the archipelago in roughly 300 CE<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> followed by later waves of immigration from the <a href="/wiki/Society_Islands" title="Society Islands">Society Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samoa" title="Samoa">Samoa</a>-<a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a>. Their languages, over time, became the Hawaiian language within the Hawaiian Islands.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> Kimura and Wilson (1983) also state: </p><blockquote><p>Linguists agree that Hawaiian is closely related to Eastern Polynesian, with a particularly strong link in the Southern Marquesas, and a secondary link in Tahiti, which may be explained by voyaging between the Hawaiian and Society Islands.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>\n<h3><span id="Methods_of_proving_Hawaiian.27s_linguistic_relationships"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Methods_of_proving_Hawaiian\'s_linguistic_relationships">Methods of proving Hawaiian\'s linguistic relationships</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Methods of proving Hawaiian&#039;s linguistic relationships">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Genetic_relationship_(linguistics)" title="Genetic relationship (linguistics)">genetic</a> history of the Hawaiian language is demonstrated primarily through the application of <a href="/wiki/Lexicostatistics" title="Lexicostatistics">lexicostatistics</a>, which involves quantitative comparison of lexical <a href="/wiki/Cognates" class="mw-redirect" title="Cognates">cognates</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Comparative_method" title="Comparative method">comparative method</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-lyovin1_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lyovin1-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> Both the number of cognates and the phonological similarity of cognates are measures of language relationship.\n</p><p>The following table provides a limited lexicostatistical data set for ten numbers.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> The asterisk (*) is used to show that these are hypothetical, <a href="/wiki/Linguistic_reconstruction" title="Linguistic reconstruction">reconstructed</a> forms. In the table, the year date of the modern forms is rounded off to 2000 CE to emphasize the 6000-year time lapse since the PAN era.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p><span class="anchor" id="Numbers"></span>\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible">\n<caption>Numbers in <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian languages</a>\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th>Language\n</th>\n<th>1\n</th>\n<th>2\n</th>\n<th>3\n</th>\n<th>4\n</th>\n<th>5\n</th>\n<th>6\n</th>\n<th>7\n</th>\n<th>8\n</th>\n<th>9\n</th>\n<th>10\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Proto-Austronesian_language" title="Proto-Austronesian language">PAN</a>, <span style="font-size:85%;"><abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;4000</span> BCE</span>\n</th>\n<td align="center">*isa\n</td>\n<td align="center">*DuSa\n</td>\n<td align="center">*telu\n</td>\n<td align="center">*Sepat\n</td>\n<td align="center">*lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">*enem\n</td>\n<td align="center">*pitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">*walu\n</td>\n<td align="center">*Siwa\n</td>\n<td align="center">*puluq\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Amis_language" title="Amis language">Amis</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">cecay\n</td>\n<td align="center">tusa\n</td>\n<td align="center">tulu\n</td>\n<td align="center">sepat\n</td>\n<td align="center">lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">enem\n</td>\n<td align="center">pitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">falu\n</td>\n<td align="center">siwa\n</td>\n<td align="center">pulu\'\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Yami_language" title="Yami language">Yami</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">asa\n</td>\n<td align="center">doa\n</td>\n<td align="center">atlo\n</td>\n<td align="center">apat\n</td>\n<td align="center">lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">anem\n</td>\n<td align="center">pito\n</td>\n<td align="center">wau\n</td>\n<td align="center">siyam\n</td>\n<td align="center">pao\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">isá\n</td>\n<td align="center">dalawá\n</td>\n<td align="center">tatló\n</td>\n<td align="center">ápat\n</td>\n<td align="center">limá\n</td>\n<td align="center">ánim\n</td>\n<td align="center">pitó\n</td>\n<td align="center">waló\n</td>\n<td align="center">siyám\n</td>\n<td align="center">sampu\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Ilokano_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Ilokano language">Ilocano</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">maysá\n</td>\n<td align="center">dua\n</td>\n<td align="center">talló\n</td>\n<td align="center">uppát\n</td>\n<td align="center">limá\n</td>\n<td align="center">inném\n</td>\n<td align="center">pitó\n</td>\n<td align="center">waló\n</td>\n<td align="center">siam\n</td>\n<td align="center">sangapúlo\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Cebuano_language" title="Cebuano language">Cebuano</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">usá\n</td>\n<td align="center">duhá\n</td>\n<td align="center">tuló\n</td>\n<td align="center">upat\n</td>\n<td align="center">limá\n</td>\n<td align="center">unom\n</td>\n<td align="center">pitó\n</td>\n<td align="center">waló\n</td>\n<td align="center">siyám\n</td>\n<td align="center">napulu\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Chamorro_language" title="Chamorro language">Chamorro</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">maisa/håcha\n</td>\n<td align="center">hugua\n</td>\n<td align="center">tulu\n</td>\n<td align="center">fatfat\n</td>\n<td align="center">lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">gunum\n</td>\n<td align="center">fiti\n</td>\n<td align="center">guålu\n</td>\n<td align="center">sigua\n</td>\n<td align="center">månot/fulu\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Malagasy_language" title="Malagasy language">Malagasy</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">isa\n</td>\n<td align="center">roa\n</td>\n<td align="center">telo\n</td>\n<td align="center">efatra\n</td>\n<td align="center">dimy\n</td>\n<td align="center">enina\n</td>\n<td align="center">fito\n</td>\n<td align="center">valo\n</td>\n<td align="center">sivy\n</td>\n<td align="center">folo\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">Malay</a>/<a href="/wiki/Indonesian_language" title="Indonesian language">Indonesian</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">sa/se/satu\n</td>\n<td align="center">dua\n</td>\n<td align="center">tiga\n</td>\n<td align="center">empat\n</td>\n<td align="center">lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">enam\n</td>\n<td align="center">tujuh\n</td>\n<td align="center">lapan/delapan\n</td>\n<td align="center">sembilan\n</td>\n<td align="center">sepuluh\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Minangkabau_language" title="Minangkabau language">Minangkabau</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">ciek/satu\n</td>\n<td align="center">duo\n</td>\n<td align="center">tigo\n</td>\n<td align="center">ampek/empat\n</td>\n<td align="center">limo\n</td>\n<td align="center">anam/enam\n</td>\n<td align="center">tujuah/tujoh\n</td>\n<td align="center">salapan/lapan\n</td>\n<td align="center">sɔmbilan\n</td>\n<td align="center">sapuluah/sepuloh\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Javanese_language" title="Javanese language">Javanese</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">siji\n</td>\n<td align="center">loro\n</td>\n<td align="center">telu\n</td>\n<td align="center">papat\n</td>\n<td align="center">lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">nem\n</td>\n<td align="center">pitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">wolu\n</td>\n<td align="center">sanga\n</td>\n<td align="center">sepuluh\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Tetum_language" title="Tetum language">Tetum</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">ida\n</td>\n<td align="center">rua\n</td>\n<td align="center">tolu\n</td>\n<td align="center">hat\n</td>\n<td align="center">lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">nen\n</td>\n<td align="center">hitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">ualu\n</td>\n<td align="center">sia\n</td>\n<td align="center">sanulu\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Fijian_language" title="Fijian language">Fijian</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">dua\n</td>\n<td align="center">rua\n</td>\n<td align="center">tolu\n</td>\n<td align="center">vā\n</td>\n<td align="center">lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">ono\n</td>\n<td align="center">vitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">walu\n</td>\n<td align="center">ciwa\n</td>\n<td align="center">tini (<span style="font-size:85%;">archaic:</span> sagavulu)\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Gilbertese_language" title="Gilbertese language">Kiribati</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">teuana\n</td>\n<td align="center">uoua\n</td>\n<td align="center">teniua\n</td>\n<td align="center">aua\n</td>\n<td align="center">nimaua\n</td>\n<td align="center">onoua\n</td>\n<td align="center">itiua\n</td>\n<td align="center">waniua\n</td>\n<td align="center">ruaiua\n</td>\n<td align="center">tebuina\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Tongan_language" title="Tongan language">Tongan</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">taha\n</td>\n<td align="center">ua\n</td>\n<td align="center">tolu\n</td>\n<td align="center">fā\n</td>\n<td align="center">nima\n</td>\n<td align="center">ono\n</td>\n<td align="center">fitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">valu\n</td>\n<td align="center">hiva\n</td>\n<td align="center">-fulu\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Samoan_language" title="Samoan language">Sāmoan</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">tasi\n</td>\n<td align="center">lua\n</td>\n<td align="center">tolu\n</td>\n<td align="center">fā\n</td>\n<td align="center">lima\n</td>\n<td align="center">ono\n</td>\n<td align="center">fitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">valu\n</td>\n<td align="center">iva\n</td>\n<td align="center">sefulu\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language" title="Māori language">Māori</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">tahi\n</td>\n<td align="center">rua\n</td>\n<td align="center">toru\n</td>\n<td align="center">whā\n</td>\n<td align="center">rima\n</td>\n<td align="center">ono\n</td>\n<td align="center">whitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">waru\n</td>\n<td align="center">iwa\n</td>\n<td align="center">tekau (<span style="font-size:85%;">archaic:</span> ngahuru)\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Tahitian_language" title="Tahitian language">Tahitian</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">hō\'ē\n</td>\n<td align="center">piti\n</td>\n<td align="center">toru\n</td>\n<td align="center">maha\n</td>\n<td align="center">pae\n</td>\n<td align="center">ōno\n</td>\n<td align="center">hitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">va\'u\n</td>\n<td align="center">iva\n</td>\n<td align="center">\'ahuru\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Marquesan_language" title="Marquesan language">Marquesan</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">tahi\n</td>\n<td align="center">\'ua\n</td>\n<td align="center">to\'u\n</td>\n<td align="center">hā\n</td>\n<td align="center">\'ima\n</td>\n<td align="center">ono\n</td>\n<td align="center">hitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">va\'u\n</td>\n<td align="center">iva\n</td>\n<td align="center">\'ahu\'u\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Leeward_Islands_(Society_Islands)" title="Leeward Islands (Society Islands)">Leeward Islands</a> dialect\n</th>\n<td align="center">tahi\n</td>\n<td align="center">rua\n</td>\n<td align="center">toru\n</td>\n<td align="center">fā\n</td>\n<td align="center">rima\n</td>\n<td align="center">ono\n</td>\n<td align="center">fitu\n</td>\n<td align="center">varu\n</td>\n<td align="center">iva\n</td>\n<td align="center">\'ahuru\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands_M%C4%81ori" title="Cook Islands Māori">Cook Islands Māori</a>\n</th>\n<td align="center">ta\'i\n</td>\n<td align="center">rua\n</td>\n<td align="center">toru\n</td>\n<td align="center">ā\n</td>\n<td align="center">rima\n</td>\n<td align="center">ono\n</td>\n<td align="center">itu\n</td>\n<td align="center">varu\n</td>\n<td align="center">iva\n</td>\n<td align="center">ta\'ingaoru\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><strong>Hawaiian</strong>\n</th>\n<td align="center">ʻekahi\n</td>\n<td align="center">ʻelua\n</td>\n<td align="center">ʻekolu\n</td>\n<td align="center">ʻehā\n</td>\n<td align="center">ʻelima\n</td>\n<td align="center">ʻeono\n</td>\n<td align="center">ʻehiku\n</td>\n<td align="center">ʻewalu\n</td>\n<td align="center">ʻeiwa\n</td>\n<td align="center">-ʻumi\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>Note: For the number "10", the Tongan form in the table is part of the word <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/hoŋo-fulu/</span> (\'ten\'). The Hawaiian cognate is part of the word <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/ana-hulu/</span> (\'ten days\'); however, the more common word for "10" used in counting and quantifying is <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/ʔumi/</span>, a different root.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>Application of the lexicostatistical method to the data in the table will show the four languages to be related to one another, with Tagalog having 100% cognacy with PAN, while Hawaiian and Tongan have 100% cognacy with each other, but 90% with Tagalog and PAN. This is because the forms for each number are cognates, except the Hawaiian and Tongan words for the number "1", which are cognate with each other, but not with Tagalog and PAN. When the full set of 200 meanings is used, the percentages will be much lower. For example, Elbert found Hawaiian and Tongan to have 49% (98 ÷ 200) shared cognacy.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> This points out the importance of data-set size for this method, where less data leads to cruder results, while more data leads to better results.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>Application of the comparative method will show partly different genetic relationships. It will point out <a href="/wiki/Sound_changes" class="mw-redirect" title="Sound changes">sound changes</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> such as:\n</p>\n<ol><li>the loss of all PAN word-final consonants in Tongan and Hawaiian;</li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Raising_(phonetics)#Raised_and_lowered_vowels" class="mw-redirect" title="Raising (phonetics)">lowering</a> of PAN <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">*u</span> to Tagalog <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[o]</span> in word-final syllables;</li>\n<li>retention of PAN <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">*t</span> in word-initial and word-medial position in Tagalog and Tongan, but shift to <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/k/</span> in Hawaiian;</li>\n<li>retention of PAN <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">*p</span> in Tagalog, but shift to <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/f/</span> in Tongan and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/h/</span> in Hawaiian.</li></ol>\n<p>This method will recognize sound change #1 as a <a href="/wiki/Comparative_method#Demonstrating_genetic_relationship" title="Comparative method">shared innovation</a> of Hawaiian and Tongan. It will also take the Hawaiian and Tongan cognates for "1" as another shared innovation. Due to these exclusively shared features, Hawaiian and Tongan are found to be more closely related to one another than either is to Tagalog or Amis.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>The forms in the table show that the Austronesian vowels tend to be relatively stable, while the consonants are relatively volatile. It is also apparent that the Hawaiian words for "3", "5", and "8" have remained essentially unchanged for 6000 years.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mutual_intelligibility">Mutual intelligibility</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Mutual intelligibility">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Jack H. Ward (1962) conducted a study using basic words and short utterances to determine the level of comprehension between different Polynesian languages. The mutual intelligibility of Hawaiian was found to be 41.2% with Marquesan, 37.5% with Tahitian, 25.5% with Samoan and 6.4% with Tongan.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For Hawaiian language history before 1778, see <a href="#Family_and_origin">§&#160;Family and origin</a>.</div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_European_contact">First European contact</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: First European contact">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>In 1778, British explorer James Cook made Europe\'s initial, recorded <a href="/wiki/First_contact_(anthropology)" title="First contact (anthropology)">first contact</a> with Hawaiʻi, beginning a new phase in the development of Hawaiian. During the next forty years, the sounds of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> (1789), <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> (1804), <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> (1816), and <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a> (1816) arrived in Hawai&#x2bb;i via other explorers and businessmen. Hawaiian began to be written for the first time, largely restricted to isolated names and words, and word lists collected by explorers and travelers.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The early explorers and merchants who first brought European languages to the Hawaiian islands also took on a few native crew members who brought the Hawaiian language into new territory.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> Hawaiians took these nautical jobs because their traditional way of life changed due to plantations, and although there were not enough of these Hawaiian-speaking explorers to establish any viable speech communities abroad, they still had a noticeable presence.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> One of them, a boy in his teens known as <a href="/wiki/Henry_Opukahaia" title="Henry Opukahaia">Obookiah</a> (<i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">&#x2bb;Ōpūkaha&#x2bb;ia</i>), had a major impact on the future of the language. He sailed to <a href="/wiki/New_England" title="New England">New England</a>, where he eventually became a student at the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Mission_School" title="Foreign Mission School">Foreign Mission School</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cornwall,_Connecticut" title="Cornwall, Connecticut">Cornwall, Connecticut</a>. He inspired New Englanders to support a Christian mission to Hawai&#x2bb;i, and provided information on the Hawaiian language to the American missionaries there prior to their departure for Hawai&#x2bb;i in 1819.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Adelbert_von_Chamisso" title="Adelbert von Chamisso">Adelbert von Chamisso</a> too might have consulted with a native speaker of Hawaiian in Berlin, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, before publishing his grammar of Hawaiian (<i><i lang="de" title="German-language text">Über die Hawaiische Sprache</i></i>) in 1837.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> \n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Folk_tales">Folk tales</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Folk tales">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<p>Like all natural spoken languages, the Hawaiian language was originally just an oral language. The native people of the Hawaiian language relayed religion, traditions, history, and views of their world through stories that were handed down from generation to generation. One form of storytelling most commonly associated with the Hawaiian islands is <a href="/wiki/Hula" title="Hula">hula</a>. Nathaniel B. Emerson notes that "It kept the communal imagination in living touch with the nation\'s legendary past".<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The islanders\' connection with their stories is argued to be one reason why Captain James Cook received a pleasant welcome. Marshall Sahlins has observed that Hawaiian folktales began bearing similar content to those of the Western world in the eighteenth century.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> He argues this was caused by the timing of Captain Cook\'s arrival, which was coincidentally when the indigenous Hawaiians were celebrating the Makahiki festival, which is the annual celebration of the harvest in honor of the god Lono. The celebration lasts for the entirety of the “rainy season”. It is a time of peace with much emphasis on amusements, food, games, and dancing.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> The islanders\' story foretold of the god Lono\'s return at the time of the Makahiki festival.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> The arrival of Captain Cook on the Endeavor with its massive white sails, unlike anything any Hawaiians had ever seen, seemed like the god Lono arriving on his floating island with white flags as it had been foretold.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Written_Hawaiian">Written Hawaiian</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Written Hawaiian">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>In 1820, <a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> <a href="/wiki/Missionaries" class="mw-redirect" title="Missionaries">missionaries</a> from <a href="/wiki/New_England" title="New England">New England</a> arrived in Hawai&#x2bb;i, and in a few years converted the chiefs to <a href="/wiki/Congregational_church" title="Congregational church">Congregational</a> Protestantism, who in turn converted their subjects. To the missionaries, the thorough Christianization of the kingdom necessitated a complete translation of the Bible to Hawaiian, a previously unwritten language, and therefore the creation of a standard spelling that should be as easy to master as possible. The orthography created by the missionaries was so straightforward that literacy spread very quickly among the adult population; at the same time, the Mission set more and more schools for children. \n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif/220px-Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="196" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif/330px-Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif/440px-Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif 2x" data-file-width="938" data-file-height="836" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Headline from May 16, 1834, issue of newspaper published by <a href="/wiki/Lorrin_Andrews" title="Lorrin Andrews">Lorrin Andrews</a> and students at <a href="/wiki/Lahainaluna" class="mw-redirect" title="Lahainaluna">Lahainaluna</a> School</div></div></div>\n<p>In 1834, the first Hawaiian-language newspapers were published by missionaries working with locals. The missionaries also played a significant role in publishing a vocabulary (1836)<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> grammar (1854)<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> and dictionary (1865)<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> of Hawaiian. The Hawaiian Bible was fully completed in 1839; by then, the Mission had such a wide-reaching school network that, when in 1840 it handed it over to the Hawaiian government, the Hawaiian Legislature mandated compulsory state-funded education for all children under 14 years of age, including girls, twelve years before any similar <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education#United_States" title="Compulsory education">compulsory education</a> law was enacted for the first time in any of the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Literacy in Hawaiian was so widespread that in 1842 a law mandated that people born after 1819 had to be literate to be allowed to marry. In his <i>Report to the Legislature</i> for the year 1853 <a href="/wiki/Richard_Armstrong_(Hawaii_missionary)" title="Richard Armstrong (Hawaii missionary)">Richard Armstrong</a>, the minister of Public Instruction, bragged that 75% of the adult population could read. <sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> Use of the language among the general population might have peaked around 1881. Even so, some people worried, as early as 1854, that the language was "soon destined to extinction."<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>When Hawaiian King <a href="/wiki/Kal%C4%81kaua" title="Kalākaua">David Kalākaua</a> took a trip around the world, he brought his native language with him. When his wife, <a href="/wiki/Queen_Kapiolani" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Kapiolani">Queen Kapi&#x2bb;olani</a>, and his sister, Princess (later Queen) <a href="/wiki/Liliuokalani" class="mw-redirect" title="Liliuokalani">Lili&#x2bb;uokalani</a>, took a trip across North America and on to the British Islands, in 1887, Lili&#x2bb;uokalani\'s composition <i><a href="/wiki/Aloha_Oe" class="mw-redirect" title="Aloha Oe">Aloha &#x2bb;Oe</a></i> was already a famous song in the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Suppression_of_Hawaiian">Suppression of Hawaiian</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Suppression of Hawaiian">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>The decline of the Hawaiian language  was accelerated by the coup that overthrew the Hawaiian monarchy and dethroned the existing Hawaiian queen. Thereafter, a law was instituted that required English as the main language of school instruction.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> The law cited is identified as Act 57, sec. 30 of the 1896 Laws of the Republic of Hawai&#x2bb;i:\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>The English Language shall be the medium and basis of instruction in all public and private schools, provided that where it is desired that another language shall be taught in addition to the English language, such instruction may be authorized by the Department, either by its rules, the curriculum of the school, or by direct order in any particular instance. Any schools that shall not conform to the provisions of this section shall not be recognized by the Department.</p><div class="templatequotecite">—&#8201;<cite>The Laws of Hawaii, Chapter 10, Section 123<sup id="cite_ref-Congress_1898_p._1-PA23_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Congress_1898_p._1-PA23-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>\n<p>This law established English as the medium of instruction for the government-recognized schools both "public and private". While it did not ban or make illegal the Hawaiian language in other contexts, its implementation in the schools had far-reaching effects. Those who had been pushing for English-only schools took this law as licence to extinguish the native language at the early education level. While the law did not make Hawaiian illegal (it was still commonly spoken at the time), many children who spoke Hawaiian at school, including on the playground, were disciplined. This included corporal punishment and going to the home of the offending child to advise them strongly to stop speaking it in their home.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> Moreover, the law specifically provided for teaching languages "in addition to the English language," reducing Hawaiian to the status of an extra language, subject to approval by the Department. Hawaiian was not taught initially in any school, including the all-Hawaiian <a href="/wiki/Kamehameha_Schools" title="Kamehameha Schools">Kamehameha Schools</a>. This is largely because when these schools were founded, like Kamehameha Schools founded in 1887 (nine years before this law), Hawaiian was being spoken in the home. Once this law was enacted, individuals at these institutions took it upon themselves to enforce a ban on Hawaiian. Beginning in 1900, Mary Kawena Pukui, who was later the co-author of the Hawaiian–English Dictionary, was punished for speaking Hawaiian by being rapped on the forehead, allowed to eat only bread and water for lunch, and denied home visits on holidays.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Winona_Beamer" title="Winona Beamer">Winona Beamer</a> was expelled from Kamehameha Schools in 1937 for chanting Hawaiian.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> Due in part to this systemic surpression of the language after the overthrow, Hawaiian is still considered a critically endangered language.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg/220px-Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg/330px-Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg/440px-Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="567" data-file-height="319" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>National origin of students in the schools of Hawaii (1890-1920)</div></div></div>\n<p>However, informal coercion to drop Hawaiian wouldn\'t have worked by itself. Just as important was the fact that, in the same period, native Hawaiians were becoming a minority in their own land on account of the growing influx of foreign labourers and their children. Whereas in 1890 pure Hawaiian students made 56% of school enrollment, in 1900 their numbers were down to 32% and, in 1910, to 16.9%. <sup id="cite_ref-:4_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> At the same time, Hawaiians were very prone to intermarriage: the number of "Part-Hawaiian" students (i.e., children of mixed Caucasian-Hawaiian marriages) grew from 1573 in 1890 to 3718 in 1910. <sup id="cite_ref-:4_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> In such mixed households, the low prestige of Hawaiian lead to the adoption of English as the family language. Moreover, Hawaiians lived mostly in the cities or scattered across the countryside, in direct contact with other ethnic groups and without any stronghold (with the exception of Niʻihau). Thus, even pure Hawaiian children would converse daily with their schoolmates of diverse mother tongues in English, which was now not just the teachers\' language but also the common language needed for everyday communication among friends and neighbours out of school as well. In only a generation English (or rather Pidgin) would become the primary and dominant language of all children, despite the efforts of Hawaiian and immigrant parents to maintain their ancestral languages within the family.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1949_to_present">1949 to present</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: 1949 to present">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>In 1949, the legislature of the Territory of Hawai&#x2bb;i commissioned Mary Pukui and Samuel Elbert to write a new dictionary of Hawaiian, either revising the Andrews-Parker work or starting from scratch.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> Pukui and Elbert took a middle course, using what they could from the Andrews dictionary, but making certain improvements and additions that were more significant than a minor revision. The dictionary they produced, in 1957, introduced an era of gradual increase in attention to the language and culture.\n</p><p>Language revitalization and Hawaiian culture has seen a major revival since the <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Renaissance" title="Hawaiian Renaissance">Hawaiian renaissance</a> in the 1970\'s. Forming in 1983, the <a href="/wiki/%CA%BBAha_P%C5%ABnana_Leo" class="mw-redirect" title="ʻAha Pūnana Leo">‘Aha Pūnana Leo</a>, meaning "language nest" in Hawaiian, opened its first center in 1984. It was a privately-funded Hawaiian preschool program that invited native Hawaiian elders to speak to children in Hawaiian everyday.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> Efforts to promote the language have increased in recent decades. Hawaiian-language "immersion" schools are now open to children whose families want to reintroduce Hawaiian language for future generations.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/P%C5%ABnana_Leo" title="Pūnana Leo">&#x2bb;Aha Pūnana Leo</a>’s Hawaiian language preschools in <a href="/wiki/Hilo,_Hawaii" title="Hilo, Hawaii">Hilo, Hawaii</a>, have received international recognition.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> The local <a href="/wiki/National_Public_Radio" class="mw-redirect" title="National Public Radio">National Public Radio</a>  station features a short segment titled "Hawaiian word of the day" and a Hawaiian language news broadcast. <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a> television station <a href="/wiki/KGMB" title="KGMB">KGMB</a> ran a weekly Hawaiian language program, <i>&#x2bb;Āha&#x2bb;i &#x2bb;Ōlelo Ola</i>, as recently as 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-Hawaii_News_Now_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hawaii_News_Now-57">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> Additionally, the Sunday editions of the <i><a href="/wiki/Honolulu_Star-Advertiser" title="Honolulu Star-Advertiser">Honolulu Star-Advertiser</a></i>, the largest newspaper in Hawaii, feature a brief article called <i>Kauakukalahale</i> written entirely in Hawaiian by teachers, students, and community members.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Today, the number of native speakers of Hawaiian, which was under 0.1% of the statewide population in 1997, has risen to 2,000, out of 24,000 total who are fluent in the language, according to the US 2011 census. On six of the seven permanently inhabited islands, Hawaiian has been largely displaced by English, but on <a href="/wiki/Ni%CA%BBihau" class="mw-redirect" title="Niʻihau">Ni&#x2bb;ihau</a>, native speakers of Hawaiian have remained fairly isolated and have continued to use Hawaiian almost exclusively.<sup id="cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_258_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lyovin_1997_258-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span id="Ni.CA.BBihau"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Niʻihau">Niʻihau</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Niʻihau">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Niʻihau is the only area in the world where Hawaiian is the first language and English is a foreign language.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup></p><div class="templatequotecite">—&#8201;<cite>Samuel Elbert and Mary Pukui, <i>Hawaiian Grammar</i> (1979)</cite></div></blockquote>\n<p>The isolated island of <a href="/wiki/Ni%CA%BBihau" class="mw-redirect" title="Niʻihau">Niʻihau</a>, located off the southwest coast of <a href="/wiki/Kauai" title="Kauai">Kauai</a>, is the one island where Hawaiian (more specifically a local dialect of Hawaiian known as <a href="/wiki/Niihau_dialect" title="Niihau dialect">Niihau dialect</a>) is still spoken as the language of daily life.<sup id="cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_258_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lyovin_1997_258-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> \n<a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:23) states that "[v]ariations in Hawaiian dialects have not been systematically studied", and that "[t]he dialect of Niʻihau is the most aberrant and the one most in need of study". They recognized that Niʻihauans can speak Hawaiian in substantially different ways. Their statements are based in part on some specific observations made by <a href="#CITEREFNewbrand1951">Newbrand (1951)</a>. (See <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology#Phonological_processes" title="Hawaiian phonology">Hawaiian phonological processes</a>)\n</p><p>Friction has developed between those on Niʻihau that speak Hawaiian as a first language, and those who speak Hawaiian as a second language, especially those educated by the <a href="/wiki/Ka_Haka_%CA%BBUla_O_Ke%CA%BBelik%C5%8Dlani,_College_of_Hawaiian_Language" class="mw-redirect" title="Ka Haka ʻUla O Keʻelikōlani, College of Hawaiian Language">College of Hawaiian Language</a> at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Hawai%CA%BBi_at_Hilo" title="University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo">University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo</a>. The University sponsors a Hawaiian Language Lexicon Committee (<i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">Kōmike Huaʻōlelo Hou</i>) which coins words for concepts that historically have not existed in the language, like "computer" and "cell phone". These words are generally not incorporated into the Niʻihau dialect, which often coins its own words organically. Some new words are Hawaiianized versions of English words, and some are composed of Hawaiian roots and unrelated to English sounds.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Hawaiian_in_schools">Hawaiian in schools</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Hawaiian in schools">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Language_immersion#Hawaii" title="Language immersion">Language immersion §&#160;Hawaii</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hawaiian_medium_schools">Hawaiian medium schools</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Hawaiian medium schools">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>The Hawaiian medium education system is a combination of charter, public, and private schools. K-6 schools operate under coordinated governance of the Department of Education and the charter school, while the preK-12 laboratory system is governed by the Department of Education, the <a href="/wiki/%CA%BBAha_P%C5%ABnana_Leo" class="mw-redirect" title="ʻAha Pūnana Leo">‘Aha Pūnana Leo</a>, and the charter school. Over 80% of graduates from these laboratory schools attend college, some of which include Ivy-League schools.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> Hawaiian is now an authorized course in the Department of Education language curriculum, though not all schools offer the language.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>There are two kinds of Hawaiian-immersion medium schools: k-12 total Hawaiian-immersion schools, and grades 7-12 partial Hawaiian immersion schools, the later having some classes are taught in English and others are taught in Hawaiian.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> One of the main focuses of Hawaiian-medium schools is to teach the form and structure of the Hawaiian language by modeling sentences as a "pepeke", meaning squid in Hawaiian.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> In this case the pepeke is a metaphor that features the body of a squid with the three essential parts: the poʻo (head), the ʻawe (tentacles) and the piko (where the poʻo and ʻawe meet) representing how a sentence is structured. The poʻo represents the predicate, the piko representing the subject and the ʻawe representing the object.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> Hawaiian immersion schools teach content that both adheres to state standards and stresses Hawaiian culture and values. The existence of immersion schools in Hawai\'i have developed the opportunity for intergenerational transmission of Hawaiian at home.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Higher_education">Higher education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Higher education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>The Ka Haka ʻUla O Keʻelikōlani <a href="/wiki/College_of_Hawaiian_Language" title="College of Hawaiian Language">College of Hawaiian Language</a> is a college at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Hawai%CA%BBi_at_Hilo" title="University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo">University of Hawaii at Hilo</a> dedicated to providing courses and programs entirely in Hawaiian. It educates and provides training for teachers and school administers of Hawaiian medium schools. It is the only college in the United States of America that offers a master\'s and doctorate\'s degree in an Indigenous language. Programs offered at The Ka Haka ʻUla O Keʻelikōlani <a href="/wiki/College_of_Hawaiian_Language" title="College of Hawaiian Language">College of Hawaiian Language</a> are known collectively as the "Hilo model" and has been imitated by the Cherokee immersion program and several other Indigenous revitalization programs.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-68">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since 1921, the University of Hawaiʻi at Manoa and all of the University of Hawaiʻi Community Colleges also offers Hawaiian language courses to students for credit. The University now also offers free online courses not for credit, along with a few other websites and apps such as <a href="/wiki/Duolingo" title="Duolingo">Duolingo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Orthography">Orthography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Orthography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_alphabet" title="Hawaiian alphabet">Hawaiian alphabet</a></div>\n<p>Hawaiians had no written language prior to Western contact, except for petroglyph symbols.\nThe modern Hawaiian alphabet, <i>ka pī&#x2bb;āpā Hawai&#x2bb;i</i>, is based on the <a href="/wiki/Latin_script" title="Latin script">Latin script</a>. Hawaiian words end <i>only</i><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> in vowels, and every consonant must be followed by a vowel. The Hawaiian alphabetical order has all of the vowels before the consonants,<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> as in the following chart.\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable">\n\n<tbody><tr style="text-align:center;">\n<th>Aa</th>\n<th>Ee</th>\n<th>Ii</th>\n<th>Oo</th>\n<th>Uu</th>\n<th>Hh</th>\n<th>Kk</th>\n<th>Ll</th>\n<th>Mm</th>\n<th>Nn</th>\n<th>Pp</th>\n<th>Ww</th>\n<th><span style="font-size: 120%;"><a href="/wiki/%CA%BBOkina" title="ʻOkina">&#x2bb;</a></span>\n</th></tr>\n<tr style="text-align:center;">\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/a/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/i/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/o/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/u/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/h/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/k~t/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/l/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/m/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/n/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/p/</span></td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/v~w/</span></td>\n<td><span class="IPA nowrap" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/<a href="/wiki/Glottal_stop" title="Glottal stop">ʔ</a>/</span>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Origin">Origin</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Origin">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>This writing system was developed by American Protestant missionaries during 1820–1826.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup> It was the first thing they ever printed in Hawai&#x2bb;i, on January 7, 1822, and it originally included the consonants <i>B, D, R, T,</i> and <i>V,</i> in addition to the current ones (<i>H, K, L, M, N, P, W</i>), and it had <i>F, G, S, Y</i> and <i>Z</i> for "spelling foreign words". The initial printing also showed the five vowel letters (<i>A, E, I, O, U</i>) and seven of the short diphthongs (<i>AE, AI, AO, AU, EI, EU, OU</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1826, the developers voted to eliminate some of the letters which represented functionally redundant <a href="/wiki/Allophone" title="Allophone">allophones</a> (called "interchangeable letters"), enabling the Hawaiian alphabet to approach the ideal state of one-symbol-one-<a href="/wiki/Phoneme" title="Phoneme">phoneme</a>, and thereby optimizing the ease with which people could teach and learn the reading and writing of Hawaiian.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> For example, instead of spelling one and the same word as <i>pule, bule, pure,</i> and <i>bure</i> (because of interchangeable <i>p/b</i> and <i>l/r</i>), the word is spelled only as <i>pule</i>.\n</p>\n<ul><li>Interchangeable B/P. <i>B</i> was dropped, <i>P</i> was kept.</li>\n<li>Interchangeable L/R. <i>R</i> and <i>D</i> were dropped, <i>L</i> was kept.</li>\n<li>Interchangeable K/T. <i>T</i> was dropped, <i>K</i> was kept.</li>\n<li>Interchangeable V/W. <i>V</i> was dropped, <i>W</i> was kept.</li></ul>\n<p>However, hundreds of words were very rapidly borrowed into Hawaiian from English, Greek, Hebrew, Latin, and Syriac.<sup id="cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_259_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lyovin_1997_259-75">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> Although these loan words were necessarily <a href="/wiki/Hawaiianize" class="mw-redirect" title="Hawaiianize">Hawaiianized</a>, they often retained some of their "non-Hawaiian letters" in their published forms.
