For example, <i>Brazil</i> fully <a href="/wiki/Hawaiianize" class="mw-redirect" title="Hawaiianize">Hawaiianized</a> is <i>Palakila</i>, but retaining "foreign letters" it is <i>Barazila</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> Another example is <i>Gibraltar</i>, written as <i>Kipalaleka</i> or <i>Gibaraleta</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> While <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[z]</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɡ]</span> are not regarded as Hawaiian sounds, <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[b]</span>, <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɹ]</span>, and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[t]</span> were represented in the original alphabet, so the letters (<i>b</i>, <i>r</i>, and <i>t</i>) for the latter are not truly "non-Hawaiian" or "foreign", even though their post-1826 use in published matter generally marked words of foreign origin.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Glottal_stop">Glottal stop</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Glottal stop">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/%CA%BBokina" class="mw-redirect" title="ʻokina">&#x2bb;okina</a></div>\n<p><i>ʻOkina</i> (<i>&#x2bb;oki</i> \'cut\' + <i>-na</i> \'-ing\') is the modern <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_name" title="Hawaiian name">Hawaiian name</a> for the symbol (a letter) that represents the <a href="/wiki/Glottal_stop" title="Glottal stop">glottal stop</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> It was formerly known as <i>&#x2bb;u&#x2bb;ina</i> ("snap").<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>For examples of the &#x2bb;okina, consider the Hawaiian words <i>Hawai&#x2bb;i</i> and <i>O&#x2bb;ahu</i> (often simply <i>Hawaii</i> and <i>Oahu</i> in English orthography). In Hawaiian, these words are pronounced <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[hʌˈʋʌi.ʔi]</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[oˈʔʌ.hu]</span>, and are written with an &#x2bb;okina where the glottal stop is pronounced.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Elbert &amp; Pukui\'s <i>Hawaiian Grammar</i> says "The glottal stop, ‘, is made by closing the glottis or space between the vocal cords, the result being something like the hiatus in English <i>oh-oh</i>."<sup id="cite_ref-:0_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="History_2">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<p>As early as 1823, the missionaries made some limited use of the apostrophe to represent the glottal stop,<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> but they did not make it a letter of the alphabet. In publishing the Hawaiian Bible, they used it to distinguish <i>ko&#x2bb;u</i> (\'my\') from <i>kou</i> (\'your\').<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> In 1864, <a href="/wiki/William_DeWitt_Alexander" title="William DeWitt Alexander">William DeWitt Alexander</a> published a grammar of Hawaiian in which he made it clear that the glottal stop (calling it "guttural break") is definitely a true consonant of the Hawaiian language.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> He wrote it using an apostrophe. In 1922, the Andrews-Parker dictionary of Hawaiian made limited use of the opening single quote symbol, then called "reversed apostrophe" or "inverse comma", to represent the glottal stop.<sup id="cite_ref-Schütz_1994_139-141_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schütz_1994_139-141-89">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> Subsequent dictionaries and written material associated with the Hawaiian language revitalization have preferred to use this symbol, the <i>&#x2bb;okina</i>, to better represent spoken Hawaiian. Nonetheless, excluding the <i>&#x2bb;okina</i> may facilitate interface with English-oriented media, or even be preferred stylistically by some Hawaiian speakers, in homage to 19th century written texts. So there is variation today in the use of this symbol.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Electronic_encoding">Electronic encoding</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Electronic encoding">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg/300px-Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="51" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg/450px-Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg/600px-Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="459" data-file-height="78" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>»<span lang="haw" style="font-style: normal;" title="Hawaiian-language text">ʻŌlelo Hawaiʻi</span>«&#160;(Hawaiian: <i>Hawaiian language</i>) within single <a href="/wiki/Quotation_mark" title="Quotation mark">quotes</a>, font: <a href="/wiki/Linux_Libertine" title="Linux Libertine">Linux Libertine</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Glyph" title="Glyph">glyph</a> of the two ʻokinas is clearly different from the one of the opening quote.</div></div></div>\n<p>The &#x2bb;okina is written in various ways for electronic uses:\n</p>\n<ul><li>turned comma: <b><span style="font-size:150%">&#x2bb;</span></b>, <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> hex value 02BB (decimal 699). This does not always have the correct appearance because it is not supported in some fonts.</li>\n<li>opening single quote, a.k.a. left single quotation mark: <b>‘</b> <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> hex value 2018 (decimal 8216). In many fonts this character looks like either a left-leaning single quotation mark or a quotation mark thicker at the bottom than at the top. In more traditional serif fonts such as <a href="/wiki/Times_New_Roman" title="Times New Roman">Times New Roman</a> it can look like a very small "6" with the circle filled in black: <span style="font-size:150%"><span style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, Garamond;"><b>‘</b></span></span>.</li></ul>\n<p>Because many people who want to write the ʻokina are not familiar with these specific characters and/or do not have access to the appropriate fonts and input and display systems, it is sometimes written with more familiar and readily available characters:\n</p>\n<ul><li>the ASCII apostrophe <b><span style="font-size:150%">\'</span></b>, <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> hex value 27 (decimal 39),<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup> following the missionary tradition.</li>\n<li>the ASCII grave accent (often called <a href="/wiki/Grave_accent#Computer-related" title="Grave accent">"backquote" or "backtick"</a>) <b><span style="font-size:150%">`</span></b>,<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> hex value 60 (decimal 96)</li>\n<li>the right single quotation mark, or "curly apostrophe" <b><span style="font-size:150%">’</span></b>, <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> hex value 2019 (decimal 8217)<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Macron">Macron</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Macron">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>A modern Hawaiian name for the <a href="/wiki/Macron_(diacritic)" title="Macron (diacritic)">macron</a> symbol is <i>kahakō</i> (<i>kaha</i> \'mark\' + <i>kō</i> \'long\').<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> It was formerly known as <i>mekona</i> (Hawaiianization of <i>macron</i>). It can be written as a <a href="/wiki/Diacritic" title="Diacritic">diacritical mark</a> which looks like a hyphen or dash written above a vowel, i.e., <i>ā ē ī ō ū</i> and <i>Ā Ē Ī Ō Ū</i>. It is used to show that the marked vowel is a "double", or "geminate", or "long" vowel, in phonological terms.<sup id="cite_ref-Elbert_1979_14-15_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elbert_1979_14-15-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> (See: <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">Vowel length</a>)\n</p><p>As early as 1821, at least one of the missionaries, <a href="/wiki/Hiram_Bingham_I" title="Hiram Bingham I">Hiram Bingham</a>, was using macrons (and <a href="/wiki/Breve" title="Breve">breves</a>) in making handwritten transcriptions of Hawaiian vowels.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup> The missionaries specifically requested their sponsor in <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a> to send them some type (fonts) with accented vowel characters, including vowels with macrons, but the sponsor made only one response and sent the wrong font size (pica instead of small pica).<sup id="cite_ref-Schütz_1994_139-141_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schütz_1994_139-141-89">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> Thus, they could not print ā, ē, ī, ō, nor ū (at the right size), even though they wanted to.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pronunciation">Pronunciation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Pronunciation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Owing to extensive <a href="/wiki/Allophony" class="mw-redirect" title="Allophony">allophony</a>, Hawaiian has more than 13 <a href="/wiki/Phone_(phonetics)" title="Phone (phonetics)">phones</a>. Although vowel length is phonemic, long vowels are not always pronounced as such,<sup id="cite_ref-Elbert_1979_14-15_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elbert_1979_14-15-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> even though under the rules for assigning stress in Hawaiian, a long vowel will always receive stress.<sup id="cite_ref-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii-96">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p><b>Writing systems</b>\n</p><p>Today, Hawaiian is written exclusively with the Latin alphabet. However, three constructed scripts for Hawaiian currently exist,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup> though they have not gained traction.\n</p><p>Nā hōʻailona ʻōlelo is an <a href="/wiki/Abugida" title="Abugida">abugida</a> created by Isaac Meyer, based on the Phoenician writing system.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> Each of the components were based on concepts that were familiar to native Hawaiians, and one such character resembles a Hale, a traditional Hawaiian home. It is written right to left, in a horizontal line, and comes with its own set of punctuation. Isaac Meyer, the creator of the abugida has also created scripts for many other languages, including <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_alphabet" title="Hebrew alphabet">Hebrew</a> adaptations for various languages.\n</p><p>The second script, Kākauna was constructed in 2018 by Hayyim Obadyah.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> Kākauna was created from the hypothesis of a native orthography existing prior to Western contact. The hypothesis also suggests ancient Hawaiians may have interpreted glottal stop not as a consonant, but as a characteristic of vowels.\n</p><p>The third script, Pī‘āpā Hou, was invented by Ben Norton,<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> who also created an alternative alphabet for English, and a script for the <a href="/wiki/Omaha%E2%80%93Ponca_language" title="Omaha–Ponca language">Omaha-Ponca</a> language.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup> Though meant for Hawaiian, the script can also be implemented in <a href="/wiki/Tahitian_language" title="Tahitian language">Tahitian</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language" title="Māori language">Māori</a>. Based on the Latin  orthography, Pī’āpā Hou makes use of the kahāko for long vowels, and the ‘okina for phonemic glottal stops. The shape of the script was inspired by Norton’s trip to <a href="/wiki/Kauai" title="Kauai">Kauaʻi</a>, specifically patterns found in the island’s nature. This script, by far has the most online material available for its use and documentation, with videos and <a href="/wiki/Font" title="Font">fonts</a> available.\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Phonology">Phonology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Phonology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology" title="Hawaiian phonology">Hawaiian phonology</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Consonants">Consonants</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Consonants">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<table class="wikitable">\n<caption>Consonants\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th>\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Labial_consonant" title="Labial consonant">Labial</a>\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Alveolar_consonant" title="Alveolar consonant">Alveolar</a>\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Velar_consonant" title="Velar consonant">Velar</a>\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Glottal_consonant" title="Glottal consonant">Glottal</a>\n</th></tr>\n<tr align="center">\n<th><a href="/wiki/Nasal_stop" class="mw-redirect" title="Nasal stop">Nasal</a>\n</th>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">m</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">n</span>\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr align="center">\n<th><a href="/wiki/Plosive_consonant" class="mw-redirect" title="Plosive consonant">Plosive</a>\n</th>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">p</span>\n</td>\n<td colspan="2"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">t ~ k</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">ʔ</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr align="center">\n<th><a href="/wiki/Fricative_consonant" class="mw-redirect" title="Fricative consonant">Fricative</a>\n</th>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">h</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr align="center">\n<th><a href="/wiki/Sonorant_consonant" class="mw-redirect" title="Sonorant consonant">Sonorant</a>\n</th>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">w ~ v</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">l ~ ɾ</span>\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>Hawaiian is known for having very few <a href="/wiki/Consonant" title="Consonant">consonant</a> phonemes&#160;– eight: <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/p, k ~ t, ʔ, h, m, n, l, w ~ v/</span>. It is notable that Hawaiian has allophonic variation of <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[t]</span> with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[k]</span>,<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Elbert_1979_22-25_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elbert_1979_22-25-104">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kinney_1956_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kinney_1956-105">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[w]</span> with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[v]</span>,<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> and (in some dialects) <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[l]</span> with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[n]</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> The <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[t]</span>–<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[k]</span> variation is quite unusual among the world\'s languages, and is likely a product both of the small number of consonants in Hawaiian, and the recent shift of historical *t to modern <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[t]</span>–<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[k]</span>, after historical *k had shifted to <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ʔ]</span>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> In some dialects, <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/ʔ/</span> remains as <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[k]</span> in some words. These variations are largely free, though there are conditioning factors. <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/l/</span> tends to <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[n]</span> especially in words with both <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/l/</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/n/</span>, such as in the island name <i>Lāna&#x2bb;i</i> (<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[laːˈnɐʔi]</span>–<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[naːˈnɐʔi]</span>), though this is not always the case: <i>&#x2bb;ele&#x2bb;ele</i> or <i>&#x2bb;ene&#x2bb;ene</i> "black". The <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[k]</span> allophone is almost universal at the beginnings of words, whereas <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[t]</span> is most common before the vowel <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/i/</span>. <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[v]</span> is also the norm after <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/i/</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span>, whereas <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[w]</span> is usual after <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/u/</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/o/</span>. After <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/a/</span> and initially, however, <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[w]</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[v]</span> are in free variation.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vowels">Vowels</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Vowels">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Hawaiian has five <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">short</a> and five <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">long</a> <a href="/wiki/Vowel" title="Vowel">vowels</a>, plus <a href="/wiki/Diphthong" title="Diphthong">diphthongs</a>.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Monophthongs">Monophthongs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Monophthongs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<table class="wikitable">\n<caption><a href="/wiki/Monophthong" title="Monophthong">Monophthongs</a>\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th rowspan="2">\n</th>\n<th colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">Short</a>\n</th>\n<th colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">Long</a>\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Front_vowel" title="Front vowel">Front</a>\n</th>\n<th><a href="/wiki/Back_vowel" title="Back vowel">Back</a>\n</th>\n<th>Front\n</th>\n<th>Back\n</th></tr>\n<tr align="center">\n<th><a href="/wiki/Close_vowel" title="Close vowel">Close</a>\n</th>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">i</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">u</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">iː</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">uː</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr align="center">\n<th><a href="/wiki/Mid_vowel" title="Mid vowel">Mid</a>\n</th>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">ɛ ~ e</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">o</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">eː</span>\n</td>\n<td><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">oː</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr align="center">\n<th><a href="/wiki/Open_vowel" title="Open vowel">Open</a>\n</th>\n<td colspan="2"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">a ~ ɐ ~ ə</span>\n</td>\n<td colspan="2"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">aː</span>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>Hawaiian has five pure vowels.  The short vowels are <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/u, i, o, e, a/</span>, and the long vowels, if they are considered separate phonemes rather than simply sequences of like vowels, are <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/uː, iː, oː, eː, aː/</span>. When stressed, short <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/a/</span> have been described as becoming <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɛ]</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɐ]</span>, while when unstressed they are <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[e]</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ə]</span><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="to back up assertion (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>. Parker Jones (2017), however, did not find a reduction of /a/ to <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ə]</span> in the phonetic analysis of a young speaker from <a href="/wiki/Hilo,_Hawaii" title="Hilo, Hawaii">Hilo, Hawaiʻi</a>; so there is at least some variation in how /a/ is realised.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-110">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span> also tends to become <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɛ]</span> next to <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/l/</span>, <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/n/</span>, and another <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ɛ]</span>, as in <i>Pele</i> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[pɛlɛ]</span>. Some grammatical particles vary between short and long vowels. These include <i>a</i> and <i>o</i> "of", <i>ma</i> "at", <i>na</i> and <i>no</i> "for". Between a back vowel <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/o/</span> or <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/u/</span> and a following non-back vowel (<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/a e i/</span>), there is an <a href="/wiki/Epenthesis" title="Epenthesis">epenthetic</a> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[w]</span>, which is generally not written. Between a front vowel <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span> or <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/i/</span> and a following non-front vowel (<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/a o u/</span>), there is an <a href="/wiki/Epenthetic" class="mw-redirect" title="Epenthetic">epenthetic</a> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[j]</span> (a <i>y</i> sound), which is never written.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Diphthongs">Diphthongs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Diphthongs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>\n<table class="wikitable">\n<caption>Short <a href="/wiki/Diphthong" title="Diphthong">diphthongs</a>&#160;\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th>\n</th>\n<th>&#160;Ending with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/u/</span>&#160;\n</th>\n<th>&#160;Ending with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/i/</span>&#160;\n</th>\n<th>&#160;Ending with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/o/</span>&#160;\n</th>\n<th>&#160;Ending with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span>&#160;\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Starting with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/i/</span>\n</th>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">iu</span>\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Starting with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/o/</span>\n</th>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">ou</span>\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">oi</span>\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Starting with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span>\n</th>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">eu</span>\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">ei</span>\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Starting with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/a/</span>\n</th>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">au</span>\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">ai</span>\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">ao</span>\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">ae</span>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The short-vowel diphthongs are <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/iu, ou, oi, eu, ei, au, ai, ao, ae/</span>. In all except perhaps <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/iu/</span>, these are <a href="/wiki/Falling_diphthong" class="mw-redirect" title="Falling diphthong">falling diphthongs</a>. However, they are not as tightly bound as the diphthongs of English, and may be considered vowel sequences.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-110">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> (The second vowel in such sequences may receive the stress, but in such cases it is not counted as a diphthong.) In fast speech, <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/ai/</span> tends to <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ei]</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/au/</span> tends to <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ou]</span>, conflating these diphthongs with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/ei/</span> and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/ou/</span>.\n</p><p>There are only a limited number of vowels which may follow long vowels, and some authors treat these sequences as diphthongs as well: <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/oːu, eːi, aːu, aːi, aːo, aːe/</span>.\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable">\n<caption>Long diphthongs&#160;\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th>\n</th>\n<th>&#160;Ending with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/u/</span>&#160;\n</th>\n<th>&#160;Ending with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/i/</span>&#160;\n</th>\n<th>&#160;Ending with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/o/</span>&#160;\n</th>\n<th>&#160;Ending with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span>&#160;\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Starting with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/o/</span>\n</th>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">oːu</span>\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Starting with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/e/</span>\n</th>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">eːi</span>\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td>\n<td>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Starting with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/a/</span>\n</th>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">aːu</span>\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">aːi</span>\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">aːo</span>\n</td>\n<td align="center"><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">aːe</span>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Phonotactics">Phonotactics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Phonotactics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology#Phonotactics" title="Hawaiian phonology">Hawaiian syllable structure</a> is (C)V. All CV syllables occur except for <i>wū</i>;<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> <i>wu</i> occurs only in two words borrowed from English.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> As shown by Schütz,<sup id="cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_259_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lyovin_1997_259-75">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii-96">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology#Stress" title="Hawaiian phonology">Hawaiian word-stress</a> is predictable in words of one to four syllables, but not in words of five or more syllables. <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology#Phonological_processes" title="Hawaiian phonology">Hawaiian phonological processes</a> include palatalization and deletion of consonants, as well as raising, diphthongization, deletion, and compensatory lengthening of vowels.<sup id="cite_ref-Elbert_1979_22-25_104-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elbert_1979_22-25-104">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kinney_1956_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kinney_1956-105">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_development">Historical development</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Historical development">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Historically, glottal stop developed from *k. <a href="/wiki/Deletion_(phonology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Deletion (phonology)">Loss</a> of intervocalic consonant phonemes has resulted in Hawaiian long vowels and diphthongs.<sup id="cite_ref-Carter_1996_373_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Carter_1996_373-115">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Grammar">Grammar</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Grammar">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_grammar" title="Hawaiian grammar">Hawaiian grammar</a></div>\n<p>Hawaiian is an <a href="/wiki/Analytic_language" title="Analytic language">analytic language</a> with <a href="/wiki/Verb%E2%80%93subject%E2%80%93object" title="Verb–subject–object">verb–subject–object</a> word order. While there is no use of <a href="/wiki/Inflection" title="Inflection">inflection</a> for verbs, in Hawaiian, like other <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_personal_pronouns" title="Austronesian personal pronouns">Austronesian personal pronouns</a>,  <a href="/wiki/Declension" title="Declension">declension</a> is found in the differentiation between a- and o-class <a href="/wiki/Genitive_case" title="Genitive case">genitive case</a> personal pronouns in order to indicate <a href="/wiki/Inalienable_possession" title="Inalienable possession">inalienable possession</a> in a binary possessive class system. Also like many Austronesian languages, Hawaiian pronouns employ separate words for <a href="/wiki/Clusivity" title="Clusivity">inclusive and exclusive we</a> (clusivity), and distinguish <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">singular</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dual_(grammatical_number)" title="Dual (grammatical number)">dual</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Plural" title="Plural">plural</a>. The grammatical function of verbs is marked by adjacent <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_particle" title="Grammatical particle">particles</a> (short words) and by their relative positions, that indicate <a href="/wiki/Tense%E2%80%93aspect%E2%80%93mood" title="Tense–aspect–mood">tense–aspect–mood</a>.\n</p><p>Some examples of verb phrase patterns:<sup id="cite_ref-:0_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<ul><li><i>ua</i> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">VERB</span></span> – <a href="/wiki/Perfective" class="mw-redirect" title="Perfective">perfective</a></li>\n<li><i>e</i> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">VERB</span></span> <i>ana</i> – <a href="/wiki/Imperfective" class="mw-redirect" title="Imperfective">imperfective</a></li>\n<li><i>ke</i> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">VERB</span></span> <i>nei</i> – <a href="/wiki/Present_progressive" class="mw-redirect" title="Present progressive">present progressive</a></li>\n<li><i>e</i> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">VERB</span></span> – <a href="/wiki/Imperative_mood" title="Imperative mood">imperative</a></li>\n<li><i>mai</i> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">VERB</span></span> – negative imperative</li>\n<li><i>i</i> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">VERB</span></span> – purposive</li>\n<li><i>ke</i> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">VERB</span></span> – infinitive</li></ul>\n<p>Nouns can be marked with <a href="/wiki/Article_(grammar)" title="Article (grammar)">articles</a>:\n</p>\n<ul><li><i>ka honu</i> (the turtle)</li>\n<li><i>nā honu</i> (the turtles)</li>\n<li><i>ka hale</i> (the house)</li>\n<li><i>ke kanaka</i> (the person)</li></ul>\n<p><i>ka</i> and <i>ke</i> are singular definite articles. <i>ke</i> is used before words beginning with a-, e-, o- and k-, and with some words beginning &#x2bb;- and p-. <i>ka</i> is used in all other cases. <i>nā</i> is the plural definite article.\n</p><p>To show part of a group, the word <i>kekahi</i> is used. To show a bigger part, <i>mau</i> is inserted to pluralize the subject.\n</p><p>Examples:\n</p>\n<ul><li><i>kekahi pipi</i> (one of the cows)</li>\n<li><i>kekahi mau pipi</i> (some of the cows)</li></ul>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Semantic_domains">Semantic domains</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Semantic domains">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>\n<p>Hawaiian has thousands of words for elements of the natural world. According to the Hawaiian Electronic Library, there are thousands of names for different types of wind, rain, parts of the sea, peaks of mountains, and sky formations, demonstrating the importance of the natural world to Hawaiian culture. For example, "Hoʻomalumalu" means "sheltering cloud" and "Hoʻoweliweli" means "threatening cloud".<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Varieties_and_debates">Varieties and debates</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Varieties and debates">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<p>There is a marked difference between varieties of the Hawaiian language spoken by most native Hawaiian elders and the Hawaiian Language taught in education, sometimes regarded as "University Hawaiian" or "College Hawaiian". "University Hawaiian" is often so different from the language spoken by elders that Native Hawaiian children may feel scared or ashamed to speak Hawaiian at home, limiting the language\'s domains to academia.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-68">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> Language varieties spoken by elders often includes <a href="/wiki/Pidgin_Hawaiian" title="Pidgin Hawaiian">Pidgin Hawaiian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Pidgin" title="Hawaiian Pidgin">Hawaiian Pidgin</a>, Hawaiian-infused English, or another variety of Hawaiian that is much different than the "University Hawaiian" that was standardized and documented by colonists in the 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-:6_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:6-120">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The divide between "University Hawaiian" and varieties spoken by elders has created debate over which variety of Hawaiian should be considered "real" or "authentic", as neither "University Hawaiian" nor other varieties spoken by elders are free from foreign interference. Hawaiian cultural beliefs of divine intervention as the driving force of language formation expedites distrust in what might be seen as the mechanical nature of colonial linguistic paradigms of language and its role in the standardized variety of "University Hawaiian".<sup id="cite_ref-:6_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:6-120">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> Hawaiian\'s authenticity debate could have major implications for revitalization efforts as language attitudes and trends in existing language domains are both UNESCO factors in assessing a language\'s level of endangerment.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1060428588">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{float:right;border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portalbox plainlist tright">\n<ul>\n<li><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Flag_of_Hawaii.svg/32px-Flag_of_Hawaii.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="16" title="Portal:Hawaii">Hawaii portal</a></span></li>\n<li><span><a href="/wiki/File:Globe_of_letters.svg" class="image"><img alt="icon" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Globe_of_letters.svg/42px-Globe_of_letters.svg.png 1.5x, href="/wiki/Portal:Languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Portal:Languages">Languages portal</a></span></li></ul></div>\n<ul><li>The <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Hawaiian_lemmas" class="extiw" title="wikt:Category:Hawaiian lemmas">list of Hawaiian words</a> and <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:English_terms_derived_from_Hawaiian" class="extiw" title="wikt:Category:English terms derived from Hawaiian">list of words of Hawaiian origin</a> at <a href="/wiki/Wiktionary" title="Wiktionary">Wiktionary</a>, a free dictionary and Wikipedia sibling project</li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_States" title="Languages of the United States">Languages of the United States</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_English_words_of_Hawaiian_origin" title="List of English words of Hawaiian origin">List of English words of Hawaiian origin</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Pidgin_Hawaiian" title="Pidgin Hawaiian">Pidgin Hawaiian</a> (not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Pidgin" title="Hawaiian Pidgin">Hawaiian Pidgin</a>)</li></ul>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist">\n<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">\n<li id="cite_note-1"><span (1977). "<span class="cs1-kern-left">"</span>Standard" versus "Dialect" in Bilingual Education: An Old Problem in a New Context". <i>The Modern Language Journal</i>. <b>61</b> (7): 315–325. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1111%2Fj.1540-4781.1977.tb05146.x">10.1111/j.1540-4781.1977.tb05146.x</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0026-7902">0026-7902</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Modern+Language+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=%22Standard%22+versus+%22Dialect%22+in+Bilingual+Education%3A+An+Old+Problem+in+a+New+Context&amp;rft.volume=61&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.pages=315-325&amp;rft.date=1977&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1111%2Fj.1540-4781.1977.tb05146.x&amp;rft.issn=0026-7902&amp;rft.aulast=Fishman&amp;rft.aufirst=Joshua+A.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-:7-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:7_9-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:7_9-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:7_9-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFHaertig1972" class="citation book cs1">Haertig, E.W. (1972). <i>Nana i Ke Kumu Vol 2</i>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hui_Hanai&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hui Hanai (page does not exist)">Hui Hanai</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Nana+i+Ke+Kumu+Vol+2&amp;rft.pub=Hui+Hanai&amp;rft.date=1972&amp;rft.aulast=Haertig&amp;rft.aufirst=E.W.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Princeton_Library-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Princeton_Library_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://library.princeton.edu/visual_materials/maps/websites/pacific/cook3/map-pacific-north-mann-1781.jpg">"Carte de l\'OCÉAN PACIFIQUE au Nord de l\'équateur / Charte des STILLEN WELTMEERS nördlichen des Äequators"</a> &#91;Chart of the PACIFIC OCEAN north of the Equator&#93; <span class="cs1-format">(JPG)</span>. <i>Princeton University Library</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2020-10-26</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Princeton+University+Library&amp;rft.atitle=Carte+de+l%27OC%C3%89AN+PACIFIQUE+au+Nord+de+l%27%C3%A9quateur+%2F+Charte+des+STILLEN+WELTMEERS+n%C3%B6rdlichen+des+%C3%84equators&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Flibrary.princeton.edu%2Fvisual_materials%2Fmaps%2Fwebsites%2Fpacific%2Fcook3%2Fmap-pacific-north-mann-1781.jpg&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span><br />\n<b>French</b>: Carte de l\'OCÉAN PACIFIQUE au Nord de l\'équateur, et des côtes qui le bornent des deux cotes: d\'après les dernières découvertes faites par les Espagnols, les Russes et les Anglais jusqu\'en 1780.<br /><b>German</b>: Charte des STILLEN WELTMEERS nördlichen des Äequators und der Küsten, die es auf beiden Seiten einschränken: Nach den neuesten, von der Spanier, Russen und Engländer bis 1780.<br /><b>English</b> (translation): Chart of the PACIFIC OCEAN north of the Equator and the Coasts that bound it on both sides: according to the latest discoveries made by the Spaniards, Russians and English up to 1780.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:44, 459)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFCarter1996">Carter (1996</a>:144, 174)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFCarter1996">Carter (1996</a>:187–188)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:41)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:61–65)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:304, 475)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:108–109)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:306)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFCarter1996">Carter (1996</a>:3 <i>Figure 1</i>)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLyovin1997">Lyovin (1997</a>:257–258)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-21">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Polynesian-languages">"Polynesian languages"</a>. <i>Encyclopedia Britannica</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2020-06-02</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclopedia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Polynesian+languages&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Ftopic%2FPolynesian-languages&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:334–336, 338 <i>20n</i>)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:35–36)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKimuraWilson1983">Kimura &amp; Wilson (1983</a>:185)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-lyovin1-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-lyovin1_25-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLyovin1997">Lyovin (1997</a>:1–12)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:322–338)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Proto-Austronesian_language" title="Proto-Austronesian language">Proto-Austronesian</a> (PAN) forms are from <a href="#CITEREFLi2004">Li (2004</a>:4).  The Tagalog forms are from <a href="#CITEREFRamos1971">Ramos (1971)</a>, the Tongan from <a href="#CITEREFChurchward1959">Churchward (1959)</a>, and the Hawaiian from <a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986)</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-:2-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:2_28-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:2_28-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:333)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLyovin1997">Lyovin (1997</a>:8–12)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-30">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFSchütz2020" class="citation book cs1">Schütz, Albert J. (2020). <i>Hawaiian Language Past, Present, and Future</i>. (1994</a>:122–126, 173–174)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Lyovin_1997_259-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_259_75-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-76">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:223)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-77">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:27, 31–32)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-78">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">Pukui &amp; Elbert href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986</a>:257, 281, 451)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-81">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:146)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-82">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:11)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-83">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986</a>:62, 275)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-84">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> In English, the glottal stop is usually either omitted, or is replaced by a non-phonemic glide, resulting in <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[hʌˈwai.i]</span> or <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[hʌˈwai.ji]</span>, and <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[oˈa.hu]</span> or <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[oˈwa.hu]</span>. Note that the latter two are essentially identical in sound.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-:0-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:0_85-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:0_85-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:10, 14, 58)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-86">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:143)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-87">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:11)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-88">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:144–145)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Schütz_1994_139-141-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Schütz_1994_139-141_89-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Schütz_1994_139-141_89-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:139–141)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.hawaiipropertytax.com/">"Hawaii County Real Property Tax Office"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2009-03-03</span></span>. <q>This site was designed to provide quick and easy access to real property tax assessment records and maps for properties located in the County of Hawaiʻi and related general information about real property tax procedures.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Hawaii+County+Real+Property+Tax+Office&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hawaiipropertytax.com%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-91">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090302152356/http://pipwerks.com/journal/2009/02/22/hawaiian-diacriticals/">"Hawaiian diacriticals"</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://pipwerks.com/journal/2009/02/22/hawaiian-diacriticals/">the original</a> on 2009-03-02<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2009-03-03</span></span>. <q>Over the last decade, there has been an attempt by many well-meaning locals (Hawaiian and non-Hawaiian) to use substitute characters when true diacriticals aren\'t available. ... This brings me to one of my pet peeves and the purpose of this post: misuse of the backtick (`) character. Many of the previously-mentioned well-intentioned folks mistakenly use a backtick to represent an ʻokina, and it drives me absolutely bonkers.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Hawaiian+diacriticals&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fpipwerks.com%2Fjournal%2F2009%2F02%2F22%2Fhawaiian-diacriticals%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-92">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.permaculture-hawaii.com/">"Laʻakea Community"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2009-03-03</span></span>. <q>Laʻakea Community formed in 2005 when a group of six people purchased Laʻakea Gardens.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=La%CA%BBakea+Community&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.permaculture-hawaii.com%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-93">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986</a>:109, 110, 156, 478)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Elbert_1979_14-15-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Elbert_1979_14-15_94-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Elbert_1979_14-15_94-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:14–15)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-95">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">Schütz (1994</a>:139, 399)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii_96-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii_96-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986</a>:xvii–xviii)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-97">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:14, 20–21)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-98">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://omniglot.com/conscripts/natlangs.htm">"Constructed scripts for natural languages"</a>. <i>omniglot.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2021-02-20</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=omniglot.com&amp;rft.atitle=Constructed+scripts+for+natural+languages&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fomniglot.com%2Fconscripts%2Fnatlangs.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-99">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://omniglot.com/conscripts/nahoailonaolelo.htm">"nā hōʻailona ʻōlelo"</a>. <i>omniglot.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Indiana University Publications in Anthropology and Linguistics.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=A+Lexicostatistical+Classification+of+the+Austronesian+Languages&amp;rft.date=1965&amp;rft.aulast=Dyen&amp;rft.aufirst=Isidore&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span> <span class="cs1-hidden-error error citation-comment">Cite journal requires <code class="cs1-code">&#124;journal=</code> (<a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#missing_periodical" title="Help:CS1 errors">help</a>)</span> Memoir 19 of the <i>International Journal of American Linguistics</i>.</li>\n<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFElbert1954" class="citation journal cs1"><a href="/wiki/Samuel_Hoyt_Elbert" title="Samuel Hoyt Elbert">Elbert, Samuel H.</a> (1954). Honolulu: The University Press of Hawaii. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-8248-0494-5" title="Special:BookSources/0-8248-0494-5"><bdi>0-8248-0494-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Hawaiian+Grammar&amp;rft.place=Honolulu&amp;rft.pub=The+University+Press+of+Hawaii&amp;rft.date=1979&amp;rft.isbn=0-8248-0494-5&amp;rft.aulast=Elbert&amp;rft.aufirst=Samuel+H.&amp;rft.au=Pukui%2C+Mary+Kawena&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></li>\n<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFFernández_Asensio2014" class="citation journal cs1">Fernández Asensio, Rubèn (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://benjamins.com/catalog/lplp.38.2.02fer">"Language policies in the Kingdom of Hawai\'i: Reassessing linguicism"</a>. <i>Language Problems &amp; Language Planning</i>. title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Learn+Hawaiian+at+Home&amp;rft.pub=Bess+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F76789116&amp;rft.isbn=1-57306-245-6&amp;rft.aulast=Wight&amp;rft.aufirst=Kahik%C4%81healani&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></li>\n<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFWilson1976" class="citation thesis cs1">Wilson, William H. (1976). <i>The <b>O</b> and <b>A</b> Possessive Markers in Hawaiian</i> (M.A. thesis). University of Hawaiʻi. <a href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/16326934">16326934</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Adissertation&amp;rft.title=The+O+and+A+Possessive+Markers+in+Hawaiian&amp;rft.degree=M.A.&amp;rft.inst=University+of+Hawai%CA%BBi&amp;rft.date=1976&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F16326934&amp;rft.aulast=Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=William+H.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language" class="Z3988"></span></li></ul>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>\n<table Program</a> (a moodle-based online study program for Hawaiian)</li>\n<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061203064044/http://ulukau.org/english.php">Ulukau (May 2010).</li>\n<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.friesian.com/hawaii.htm#pronounce">How to Pronounce "Hawai\'i"</a>, Kelley L. (May 2012).</li></ul>\n<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1057682214">.mw-parser-output .navbox{box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid in Hawaii">Tourism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Hawaii" title="Transportation in Hawaii">Transportation</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Hawaii" class="mw-redirect" title="Favorlang language">Favorlang</a> †</li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Papora-Hoanya_language" title="Papora-Hoanya language">Papora-Hoanya</a> †</li></ul>\n</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/East_Formosan_languages" title="East Formosan languages">East title="Category:Endangered Austronesian languages">Endangered Austronesian languages</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Endangered_languages_of_Oceania" title="Category:Endangered languages of Oceania">Endangered languages of Oceania</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Verb%E2%80%93subject%E2%80%93object_languages" title="Category:Verb–subject–object languages">Verb–subject–object languages</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Languages_attested_from_the_18th_century" title="Category:Languages attested from the 18th century">Languages attested from the 18th century</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:18th-century_establishments_in_North_America" title="Category:18th-century establishments in North America">18th-century establishments in North America</a></li></ul></div><div id="mw-hidden-catlinks" class="mw-hidden-catlinks mw-hidden-cats-hidden">Hidden categories: <ul><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Articles_with_short_description" menu</h2>\n\t<div id="mw-head">\n\t\t<nav id="p-personal" class="mw-portlet mw-portlet-personal vector-user-menu-legacy vector-menu" aria-labelledby="p-personal-label" role="navigation" \n\t >\n\t<h3    <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading">
    Hawaiian language
   </h1>
   <div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>

    </div>

     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Polynesian language
      </div>
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1048617464">
       .mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .infobox-3cols-child{margin:auto}
      </style>
      <table class="infobox vevent">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <th class="infobox-above above" colspan="2" style="font-size:125%; color: black; background-color: pink;">
          Hawaiian
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td class="infobox-subheader" colspan="2" style="font-size:110%; color: black; background-color: pink;">
          <i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">
           ʻŌlelo Hawaiʻi
          </i>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">
          Native to
         </th>
         <td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;">
          <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands" title="Hawaiian Islands">
           Hawaiian Islands
          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">
          Region
         </th>

          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/Niihau" title="Niihau">
           Niʻihau
          </a>

           <a href="#cite_note-1">
            [1]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </td>
        </tr>

          </a>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">

          </div>
         </th>
         <td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;">
          ~24,000 (2008)
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">

            </a>

                   </a>

                    <li>

                     </a>

                       </b>
                      </li>
                     </ul>
                    </li>
                   </ul>
                  </li>

                </li>

              </li>

            </li>

          </div>

        </tr>
        <tr class="plainlist">
         <th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">
          Dialects
         </th>
         <td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;">
          <ul>
           <li>
            Standard Hawaiian
           </li>
           <li>

             Niihau dialect
            </a>
           </li>
