       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For example, instead of spelling one and the same word as
       <i>
        pule, bule, pure,
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        bure
       </i>
       (because of interchangeable
       <i>
        p/b
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        l/r
       </i>
       ), the word is spelled only as
       <i>
        pule
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Interchangeable B/P.
        <i>
         B
        </i>
        was dropped,
        <i>
         P
        </i>
        was kept.
       </li>
       <li>
        Interchangeable L/R.
        <i>
         R
        </i>
        and
        <i>
         D
        </i>
        were dropped,
        <i>
         L
        </i>
        was kept.
       </li>
       <li>
        Interchangeable K/T.
        <i>
         T
        </i>
        was dropped,
        <i>
         K
        </i>
        was kept.
       </li>
       <li>
        Interchangeable V/W.
        <i>
         V
        </i>
        was dropped,
        <i>
         W
        </i>
        was kept.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       However, hundreds of words were very rapidly borrowed into Hawaiian from English, Greek, Hebrew, Latin, and Syriac.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_259_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lyovin_1997_259-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Although these loan words were necessarily
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hawaiianize" title="Hawaiianize">
        Hawaiianized
       </a>
       , they often retained some of their "non-Hawaiian letters" in their published forms. For example,
       <i>
        Brazil
       </i>
       fully
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hawaiianize" title="Hawaiianize">
        Hawaiianized
       </a>
       is
       <i>
        Palakila
       </i>
       , but retaining "foreign letters" it is
       <i>
        Barazila
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Another example is
       <i>
        Gibraltar
       </i>
       , written as
       <i>
        Kipalaleka
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        Gibaraleta
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       While
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [z]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ɡ]
       </span>
       are not regarded as Hawaiian sounds,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [b]
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ɹ]
       </span>
       , and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [t]
       </span>
       were represented in the original alphabet, so the letters (
       <i>
        b
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        r
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        t
       </i>
       ) for the latter are not truly "non-Hawaiian" or "foreign", even though their post-1826 use in published matter generally marked words of foreign origin.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Glottal_stop">
        Glottal stop
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Glottal stop">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%CA%BBokina" title="ʻokina">
        ʻokina
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       <i>
        ʻOkina
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        ʻoki
       </i>
       'cut' +
       <i>
        -na
       </i>
       '-ing') is the modern
       <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_name" title="Hawaiian name">
        Hawaiian name
       </a>
       for the symbol (a letter) that represents the
       <a href="/wiki/Glottal_stop" title="Glottal stop">
        glottal stop
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It was formerly known as
       <i>
        ʻuʻina
       </i>
       ("snap").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       For examples of the ʻokina, consider the Hawaiian words
       <i>
        Hawaiʻi
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Oʻahu
       </i>
       (often simply
       <i>
        Hawaii
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Oahu
       </i>
       in English orthography). In Hawaiian, these words are pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [hʌˈʋʌi.ʔi]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [oˈʔʌ.hu]
       </span>
       , and are written with an ʻokina where the glottal stop is pronounced.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Elbert &amp; Pukui's
       <i>
        Hawaiian Grammar
       </i>
       says "The glottal stop, ‘, is made by closing the glottis or space between the vocal cords, the result being something like the hiatus in English
       <i>
        oh-oh
       </i>
       ."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_85-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-:0-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History_2">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       As early as 1823, the missionaries made some limited use of the apostrophe to represent the glottal stop,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but they did not make it a letter of the alphabet. In publishing the Hawaiian Bible, they used it to distinguish
       <i>
        koʻu
       </i>
       ('my') from
       <i>
        kou
       </i>
       ('your').
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
        <a href="#cite_note-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1864,
       <a href="/wiki/William_DeWitt_Alexander" title="William DeWitt Alexander">
        William DeWitt Alexander
       </a>
       published a grammar of Hawaiian in which he made it clear that the glottal stop (calling it "guttural break") is definitely a true consonant of the Hawaiian language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He wrote it using an apostrophe. In 1922, the Andrews-Parker dictionary of Hawaiian made limited use of the opening single quote symbol, then called "reversed apostrophe" or "inverse comma", to represent the glottal stop.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schütz_1994_139-141_89-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Schütz_1994_139-141-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Subsequent dictionaries and written material associated with the Hawaiian language revitalization have preferred to use this symbol, the
       <i>
        ʻokina
       </i>
       , to better represent spoken Hawaiian. Nonetheless, excluding the
       <i>
        ʻokina
       </i>
       may facilitate interface with English-oriented media, or even be preferred stylistically by some Hawaiian speakers, in homage to 19th century written texts. So there is variation today in the use of this symbol.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Electronic_encoding">
        Electronic encoding
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Electronic encoding">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="78" data-file-width="459" decoding="async" height="51" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg/300px-Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg/450px-Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg/600px-Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Okina-using-Linux-Libertine.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         »
         <span lang="haw" style="font-style: normal;" title="Hawaiian-language text">
          ʻŌlelo Hawaiʻi
         </span>
         « (Hawaiian:
         <i>
          Hawaiian language
         </i>
         ) within single
         <a href="/wiki/Quotation_mark" title="Quotation mark">
          quotes
         </a>
         , font:
         <a href="/wiki/Linux_Libertine" title="Linux Libertine">
          Linux Libertine
         </a>
         . The
         <a href="/wiki/Glyph" title="Glyph">
          glyph
         </a>
         of the two ʻokinas is clearly different from the one of the opening quote.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The ʻokina is written in various ways for electronic uses:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        turned comma:
        <b>
         <span style="font-size:150%">
          ʻ
         </span>
        </b>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
         Unicode
        </a>
        hex value 02BB (decimal 699). This does not always have the correct appearance because it is not supported in some fonts.
       </li>
       <li>
        opening single quote, a.k.a. left single quotation mark:
        <b>
         ‘
        </b>
        <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
         Unicode
        </a>
        hex value 2018 (decimal 8216). In many fonts this character looks like either a left-leaning single quotation mark or a quotation mark thicker at the bottom than at the top. In more traditional serif fonts such as
        <a href="/wiki/Times_New_Roman" title="Times New Roman">
         Times New Roman
        </a>
        it can look like a very small "6" with the circle filled in black:
        <span style="font-size:150%">
         <span style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, Garamond;">
          <b>
           ‘
          </b>
         </span>
        </span>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Because many people who want to write the ʻokina are not familiar with these specific characters and/or do not have access to the appropriate fonts and input and display systems, it is sometimes written with more familiar and readily available characters:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        the ASCII apostrophe
        <b>
         <span style="font-size:150%">
          '
         </span>
        </b>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
         Unicode
        </a>
        hex value 27 (decimal 39),
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
         <a href="#cite_note-90">
          [90]
         </a>
        </sup>
        following the missionary tradition.
       </li>
       <li>
        the ASCII grave accent (often called
        <a href="/wiki/Grave_accent#Computer-related" title="Grave accent">
         "backquote" or "backtick"
        </a>
        )
        <b>
         <span style="font-size:150%">
          `
         </span>
        </b>
        ,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
         <a href="#cite_note-91">
          [91]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
         Unicode
        </a>
        hex value 60 (decimal 96)
       </li>
       <li>
        the right single quotation mark, or "curly apostrophe"
        <b>
         <span style="font-size:150%">
          ’
         </span>
        </b>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
         Unicode
        </a>
        hex value 2019 (decimal 8217)
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
         <a href="#cite_note-92">
          [92]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Macron">
        Macron
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Macron">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       A modern Hawaiian name for the
       <a href="/wiki/Macron_(diacritic)" title="Macron (diacritic)">
        macron
       </a>
       symbol is
       <i>
        kahakō
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        kaha
       </i>
       'mark' +
       <i>
        kō
       </i>
       'long').
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It was formerly known as
       <i>
        mekona
       </i>
       (Hawaiianization of
       <i>
        macron
       </i>
       ). It can be written as a
       <a href="/wiki/Diacritic" title="Diacritic">
        diacritical mark
       </a>
       which looks like a hyphen or dash written above a vowel, i.e.,
       <i>
        ā ē ī ō ū
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Ā Ē Ī Ō Ū
       </i>
       . It is used to show that the marked vowel is a "double", or "geminate", or "long" vowel, in phonological terms.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elbert_1979_14-15_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Elbert_1979_14-15-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (See:
       <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">
        Vowel length
       </a>
       )
      </p>
      <p>
       As early as 1821, at least one of the missionaries,
       <a href="/wiki/Hiram_Bingham_I" title="Hiram Bingham I">
        Hiram Bingham
       </a>
       , was using macrons (and
       <a href="/wiki/Breve" title="Breve">
        breves
       </a>
       ) in making handwritten transcriptions of Hawaiian vowels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The missionaries specifically requested their sponsor in
       <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">
        Boston
       </a>
       to send them some type (fonts) with accented vowel characters, including vowels with macrons, but the sponsor made only one response and sent the wrong font size (pica instead of small pica).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schütz_1994_139-141_89-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Schütz_1994_139-141-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Thus, they could not print ā, ē, ī, ō, nor ū (at the right size), even though they wanted to.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Pronunciation">
        Pronunciation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Pronunciation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Owing to extensive
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Allophony" title="Allophony">
        allophony
       </a>
       , Hawaiian has more than 13
       <a href="/wiki/Phone_(phonetics)" title="Phone (phonetics)">
        phones
       </a>
       . Although vowel length is phonemic, long vowels are not always pronounced as such,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elbert_1979_14-15_94-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Elbert_1979_14-15-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       even though under the rules for assigning stress in Hawaiian, a long vowel will always receive stress.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <b>
        Writing systems
       </b>
      </p>
      <p>
       Today, Hawaiian is written exclusively with the Latin alphabet. However, three constructed scripts for Hawaiian currently exist,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       though they have not gained traction.
      </p>
      <p>
       Nā hōʻailona ʻōlelo is an
       <a href="/wiki/Abugida" title="Abugida">
        abugida
       </a>
       created by Isaac Meyer, based on the Phoenician writing system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Each of the components were based on concepts that were familiar to native Hawaiians, and one such character resembles a Hale, a traditional Hawaiian home. It is written right to left, in a horizontal line, and comes with its own set of punctuation. Isaac Meyer, the creator of the abugida has also created scripts for many other languages, including
       <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_alphabet" title="Hebrew alphabet">
        Hebrew
       </a>
       adaptations for various languages.
      </p>
      <p>
       The second script, Kākauna was constructed in 2018 by Hayyim Obadyah.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Kākauna was created from the hypothesis of a native orthography existing prior to Western contact. The hypothesis also suggests ancient Hawaiians may have interpreted glottal stop not as a consonant, but as a characteristic of vowels.
      </p>
      <p>
       The third script, Pī‘āpā Hou, was invented by Ben Norton,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       who also created an alternative alphabet for English, and a script for the
       <a href="/wiki/Omaha%E2%80%93Ponca_language" title="Omaha–Ponca language">
        Omaha-Ponca
       </a>
       language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Though meant for Hawaiian, the script can also be implemented in
       <a href="/wiki/Tahitian_language" title="Tahitian language">
        Tahitian
       </a>
       &amp;
       <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language" title="Māori language">
        Māori
       </a>
       . Based on the Latin  orthography, Pī’āpā Hou makes use of the kahāko for long vowels, and the ‘okina for phonemic glottal stops. The shape of the script was inspired by Norton’s trip to
       <a href="/wiki/Kauai" title="Kauai">
        Kauaʻi
       </a>
       , specifically patterns found in the island’s nature. This script, by far has the most online material available for its use and documentation, with videos and
       <a href="/wiki/Font" title="Font">
        fonts
       </a>
       available.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Phonology">
        Phonology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Phonology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology" title="Hawaiian phonology">
        Hawaiian phonology
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Consonants">
        Consonants
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Consonants">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <caption>
        Consonants
       </caption>
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <th>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Labial_consonant" title="Labial consonant">
           Labial
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Alveolar_consonant" title="Alveolar consonant">
           Alveolar
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Velar_consonant" title="Velar consonant">
           Velar
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Glottal_consonant" title="Glottal consonant">
           Glottal
          </a>
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr align="center">
         <th>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nasal_stop" title="Nasal stop">
           Nasal
          </a>
         </th>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           m
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           n
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr align="center">
         <th>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plosive_consonant" title="Plosive consonant">
           Plosive
          </a>
         </th>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           p
          </span>
         </td>
         <td colspan="2">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           t ~ k
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           ʔ
          </span>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr align="center">
         <th>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fricative_consonant" title="Fricative consonant">
           Fricative
          </a>
         </th>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           h
          </span>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr align="center">
         <th>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sonorant_consonant" title="Sonorant consonant">
           Sonorant
          </a>
         </th>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           w ~ v
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           l ~ ɾ
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>
      <p>
       Hawaiian is known for having very few
       <a href="/wiki/Consonant" title="Consonant">
        consonant
       </a>
       phonemes – eight:
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /p, k ~ t, ʔ, h, m, n, l, w ~ v/
       </span>
       . It is notable that Hawaiian has allophonic variation of
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [t]
       </span>
       with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [k]
       </span>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elbert_1979_22-25_104-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Elbert_1979_22-25-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kinney_1956_105-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kinney_1956-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [w]
       </span>
       with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [v]
       </span>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and (in some dialects)
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [l]
       </span>
       with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [n]
       </span>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
        <a href="#cite_note-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [t]
       </span>
       –
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [k]
       </span>
       variation is quite unusual among the world's languages, and is likely a product both of the small number of consonants in Hawaiian, and the recent shift of historical *t to modern
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [t]
       </span>
       –
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [k]
       </span>
       , after historical *k had shifted to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ʔ]
       </span>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2021)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In some dialects,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʔ/
       </span>
       remains as
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [k]
       </span>
       in some words. These variations are largely free, though there are conditioning factors.
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /l/
       </span>
       tends to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [n]
       </span>
       especially in words with both
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /l/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /n/
       </span>
       , such as in the island name
       <i>
        Lānaʻi
       </i>
       (
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [laːˈnɐʔi]
       </span>
       –
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [naːˈnɐʔi]
       </span>
       ), though this is not always the case:
       <i>
        ʻeleʻele
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        ʻeneʻene
       </i>
       "black". The
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [k]
       </span>
       allophone is almost universal at the beginnings of words, whereas
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [t]
       </span>
       is most common before the vowel
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /i/
       </span>
       .
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [v]
       </span>
       is also the norm after
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /i/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e/
       </span>
       , whereas
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [w]
       </span>
       is usual after
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       . After
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /a/
       </span>
       and initially, however,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [w]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [v]
       </span>
       are in free variation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Vowels">
        Vowels
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Vowels">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Hawaiian has five
       <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">
        short
       </a>
       and five
       <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">
        long
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Vowel" title="Vowel">
        vowels
       </a>
       , plus
       <a href="/wiki/Diphthong" title="Diphthong">
        diphthongs
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Monophthongs">
        Monophthongs
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Monophthongs">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <caption>
        <a href="/wiki/Monophthong" title="Monophthong">
         Monophthongs
        </a>
       </caption>
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <th rowspan="2">
         </th>
         <th colspan="2">
          <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">
           Short
          </a>
         </th>
         <th colspan="2">
          <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">
           Long
          </a>
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Front_vowel" title="Front vowel">
           Front
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Back_vowel" title="Back vowel">
           Back
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          Front
         </th>
         <th>
          Back
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr align="center">
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Close_vowel" title="Close vowel">
           Close
          </a>
         </th>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           i
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           u
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           iː
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           uː
          </span>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr align="center">
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Mid_vowel" title="Mid vowel">
           Mid
          </a>
         </th>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           ɛ ~ e
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           o
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           eː
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           oː
          </span>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr align="center">
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Open_vowel" title="Open vowel">
           Open
          </a>
         </th>
         <td colspan="2">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           a ~ ɐ ~ ə
          </span>
         </td>
         <td colspan="2">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           aː
          </span>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>
      <p>
       Hawaiian has five pure vowels.  The short vowels are
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u, i, o, e, a/
       </span>
       , and the long vowels, if they are considered separate phonemes rather than simply sequences of like vowels, are
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /uː, iː, oː, eː, aː/
       </span>
       . When stressed, short
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /a/
       </span>
       have been described as becoming
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ɛ]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ɐ]
       </span>
       , while when unstressed they are
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [e]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ə]
       </span>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="to back up assertion (September 2018)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       . Parker Jones (2017), however, did not find a reduction of /a/ to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ə]
       </span>
       in the phonetic analysis of a young speaker from
       <a href="/wiki/Hilo,_Hawaii" title="Hilo, Hawaii">
        Hilo, Hawaiʻi
       </a>
       ; so there is at least some variation in how /a/ is realised.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_110-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-:3-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e/
       </span>
       also tends to become
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ɛ]
       </span>
       next to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /l/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /n/
       </span>
       , and another
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ɛ]
       </span>
       , as in
       <i>
        Pele
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [pɛlɛ]
       </span>
       . Some grammatical particles vary between short and long vowels. These include
       <i>
        a
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        o
       </i>
       "of",
       <i>
        ma
       </i>
       "at",
       <i>
        na
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        no
       </i>
       "for". Between a back vowel
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       or
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/
       </span>
       and a following non-back vowel (
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /a e i/
       </span>
       ), there is an
       <a href="/wiki/Epenthesis" title="Epenthesis">
        epenthetic
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [w]
       </span>
       , which is generally not written. Between a front vowel
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e/
       </span>
       or
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /i/
       </span>
       and a following non-front vowel (
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /a o u/
       </span>
       ), there is an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epenthetic" title="Epenthetic">
        epenthetic
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [j]
       </span>
       (a
       <i>
        y
       </i>
       sound), which is never written.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Diphthongs">
        Diphthongs
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Diphthongs">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <caption>
        Short
        <a href="/wiki/Diphthong" title="Diphthong">
         diphthongs
        </a>
       </caption>
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <th>
         </th>
         <th>
          Ending with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /u/
          </span>
         </th>
         <th>
          Ending with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /i/
          </span>
         </th>
         <th>
          Ending with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /o/
          </span>
         </th>
         <th>
          Ending with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /e/
          </span>
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th>
          Starting with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /i/
          </span>
         </th>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           iu
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th>
          Starting with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /o/
          </span>
         </th>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           ou
          </span>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           oi
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th>
          Starting with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /e/
          </span>
         </th>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           eu
          </span>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           ei
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th>
          Starting with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /a/
          </span>
         </th>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           au
          </span>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           ai
          </span>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           ao
          </span>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           ae
          </span>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>
      <p>
       The short-vowel diphthongs are
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /iu, ou, oi, eu, ei, au, ai, ao, ae/
       </span>
       . In all except perhaps
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /iu/
       </span>
       , these are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Falling_diphthong" title="Falling diphthong">
        falling diphthongs
       </a>
       . However, they are not as tightly bound as the diphthongs of English, and may be considered vowel sequences.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_110-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-:3-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (The second vowel in such sequences may receive the stress, but in such cases it is not counted as a diphthong.) In fast speech,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ai/
       </span>
       tends to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ei]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /au/
       </span>
       tends to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ou]
       </span>
       , conflating these diphthongs with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ei/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ou/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       There are only a limited number of vowels which may follow long vowels, and some authors treat these sequences as diphthongs as well:
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /oːu, eːi, aːu, aːi, aːo, aːe/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <caption>
        Long diphthongs
       </caption>
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <th>
         </th>
         <th>
          Ending with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /u/
          </span>
         </th>
         <th>
          Ending with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /i/
          </span>
         </th>
         <th>
          Ending with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /o/
          </span>
         </th>
         <th>
          Ending with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /e/
          </span>
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th>
          Starting with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /o/
          </span>
         </th>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           oːu
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th>
          Starting with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /e/
          </span>
         </th>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           eːi
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
         <td>
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th>
          Starting with
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /a/
          </span>
         </th>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           aːu
          </span>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           aːi
          </span>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           aːo
          </span>
         </td>
         <td align="center">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           aːe
          </span>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Phonotactics">
        Phonotactics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Phonotactics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology#Phonotactics" title="Hawaiian phonology">
        Hawaiian syllable structure
       </a>
       is (C)V. All CV syllables occur except for
       <i>
        wū
       </i>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <i>
        wu
       </i>
       occurs only in two words borrowed from English.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As shown by Schütz,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_259_75-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lyovin_1997_259-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii_96-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pukui_1986_xvii–xviii-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology#Stress" title="Hawaiian phonology">
        Hawaiian word-stress
       </a>
       is predictable in words of one to four syllables, but not in words of five or more syllables.
       <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology#Phonological_processes" title="Hawaiian phonology">
        Hawaiian phonological processes
       </a>
       include palatalization and deletion of consonants, as well as raising, diphthongization, deletion, and compensatory lengthening of vowels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elbert_1979_22-25_104-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Elbert_1979_22-25-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kinney_1956_105-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kinney_1956-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_development">
        Historical development
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Historical development">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Historically, glottal stop developed from *k.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deletion_(phonology)" title="Deletion (phonology)">
        Loss
       </a>
       of intervocalic consonant phonemes has resulted in Hawaiian long vowels and diphthongs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carter_1996_373_115-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Carter_1996_373-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Grammar">
        Grammar
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Grammar">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_grammar" title="Hawaiian grammar">
        Hawaiian grammar
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hawaiian is an
       <a href="/wiki/Analytic_language" title="Analytic language">
        analytic language
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Verb%E2%80%93subject%E2%80%93object" title="Verb–subject–object">
        verb–subject–object
       </a>
       word order. While there is no use of
       <a href="/wiki/Inflection" title="Inflection">
        inflection
       </a>
       for verbs, in Hawaiian, like other
       <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_personal_pronouns" title="Austronesian personal pronouns">
        Austronesian personal pronouns
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Declension" title="Declension">
        declension
       </a>
       is found in the differentiation between a- and o-class
       <a href="/wiki/Genitive_case" title="Genitive case">
        genitive case
       </a>
       personal pronouns in order to indicate
       <a href="/wiki/Inalienable_possession" title="Inalienable possession">
        inalienable possession
       </a>
       in a binary possessive class system. Also like many Austronesian languages, Hawaiian pronouns employ separate words for
       <a href="/wiki/Clusivity" title="Clusivity">
        inclusive and exclusive we
       </a>
       (clusivity), and distinguish
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">
        singular
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dual_(grammatical_number)" title="Dual (grammatical number)">
        dual
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Plural" title="Plural">
        plural
       </a>
       . The grammatical function of verbs is marked by adjacent
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_particle" title="Grammatical particle">
        particles
       </a>
       (short words) and by their relative positions, that indicate
       <a href="/wiki/Tense%E2%80%93aspect%E2%80%93mood" title="Tense–aspect–mood">
        tense–aspect–mood
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Some examples of verb phrase patterns:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_85-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-:0-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <i>
         ua
        </i>
        <span class="smallcaps">
         <span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">
          VERB
         </span>
        </span>
        –
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perfective" title="Perfective">
         perfective
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         e
        </i>
        <span class="smallcaps">
         <span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">
          VERB
         </span>
        </span>
        <i>
         ana
        </i>
        –
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperfective" title="Imperfective">
         imperfective
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         ke
        </i>
        <span class="smallcaps">
         <span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">
          VERB
         </span>
        </span>
        <i>
         nei
        </i>
        –
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Present_progressive" title="Present progressive">
         present progressive
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         e
        </i>
        <span class="smallcaps">
         <span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">
          VERB
         </span>
        </span>
        –
        <a href="/wiki/Imperative_mood" title="Imperative mood">
         imperative
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         mai
        </i>
        <span class="smallcaps">
         <span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">
          VERB
         </span>
        </span>
        – negative imperative
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         i
        </i>
        <span class="smallcaps">
         <span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">
          VERB
         </span>
        </span>
        – purposive
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         ke
        </i>
        <span class="smallcaps">
         <span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">
          VERB
         </span>
        </span>
        – infinitive
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Nouns can be marked with
       <a href="/wiki/Article_(grammar)" title="Article (grammar)">
        articles
       </a>
       :
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <i>
         ka honu
        </i>
        (the turtle)
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         nā honu
        </i>
        (the turtles)
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         ka hale
        </i>
        (the house)
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         ke kanaka
        </i>
        (the person)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       <i>
        ka
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        ke
       </i>
       are singular definite articles.
       <i>
        ke
       </i>
       is used before words beginning with a-, e-, o- and k-, and with some words beginning ʻ- and p-.
       <i>
        ka
       </i>
       is used in all other cases.
       <i>
        nā
       </i>
       is the plural definite article.
      </p>
      <p>
       To show part of a group, the word
       <i>
        kekahi
       </i>
       is used. To show a bigger part,
       <i>
        mau
       </i>
       is inserted to pluralize the subject.
      </p>
      <p>
       Examples:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <i>
         kekahi pipi
        </i>
        (one of the cows)
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         kekahi mau pipi
        </i>
        (some of the cows)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Semantic_domains">
        Semantic domains
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Semantic domains">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Hawaiian has thousands of words for elements of the natural world. According to the Hawaiian Electronic Library, there are thousands of names for different types of wind, rain, parts of the sea, peaks of mountains, and sky formations, demonstrating the importance of the natural world to Hawaiian culture. For example, "Hoʻomalumalu" means "sheltering cloud" and "Hoʻoweliweli" means "threatening cloud".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Varieties_and_debates">
        Varieties and debates
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Varieties and debates">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       There is a marked difference between varieties of the Hawaiian language spoken by most native Hawaiian elders and the Hawaiian Language taught in education, sometimes regarded as "University Hawaiian" or "College Hawaiian". "University Hawaiian" is often so different from the language spoken by elders that Native Hawaiian children may feel scared or ashamed to speak Hawaiian at home, limiting the language's domains to academia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_68-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-:5-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Language varieties spoken by elders often includes
       <a href="/wiki/Pidgin_Hawaiian" title="Pidgin Hawaiian">
        Pidgin Hawaiian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Pidgin" title="Hawaiian Pidgin">
        Hawaiian Pidgin
       </a>
       , Hawaiian-infused English, or another variety of Hawaiian that is much different than the "University Hawaiian" that was standardized and documented by colonists in the 19th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_120-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-:6-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The divide between "University Hawaiian" and varieties spoken by elders has created debate over which variety of Hawaiian should be considered "real" or "authentic", as neither "University Hawaiian" nor other varieties spoken by elders are free from foreign interference. Hawaiian cultural beliefs of divine intervention as the driving force of language formation expedites distrust in what might be seen as the mechanical nature of colonial linguistic paradigms of language and its role in the standardized variety of "University Hawaiian".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_120-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-:6-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hawaiian's authenticity debate could have major implications for revitalization efforts as language attitudes and trends in existing language domains are both UNESCO factors in assessing a language's level of endangerment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
        See also
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: See also">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1060428588">
       .mw-parser-output .portalbox{float:right;border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}
      </style>
      <div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portalbox plainlist tright" role="navigation">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>

         </span>

           Hawaii portal
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Globe_of_letters.svg">
           <img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Globe_of_letters.svg/28px-Globe_of_letters.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Globe_of_letters.svg/42px-Globe_of_letters.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Globe_of_letters.svg/56px-Globe_of_letters.svg.png 2x" width="28"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:Languages" title="Portal:Languages">
           Languages portal
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Hawaiian_lemmas" title="wikt:Category:Hawaiian lemmas">
         list of Hawaiian words
        </a>
        and
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:English_terms_derived_from_Hawaiian" title="wikt:Category:English terms derived from Hawaiian">
         list of words of Hawaiian origin
        </a>
        at
        <a href="/wiki/Wiktionary" title="Wiktionary">
         Wiktionary
        </a>
        , a free dictionary and Wikipedia sibling project
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_States" title="Languages of the United States">
         Languages of the United States
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_English_words_of_Hawaiian_origin" title="List of English words of Hawaiian origin">
         List of English words of Hawaiian origin
        </a>
       </li>

        <a href="/wiki/Pidgin_Hawaiian" title="Pidgin Hawaiian">
         Pidgin Hawaiian
        </a>
        (not to be confused with
        <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Pidgin" title="Hawaiian Pidgin">
         Hawaiian Pidgin
        </a>
        )
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="References">
        References
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">

         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">
       .mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}
      </style>
      <div class="reflist">
       <div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns">
        <ol class="references">
         <li id="cite_note-1">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-1">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r999302996">
            .mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration{color:#555}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription span,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration span{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output code.cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#33aa33;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}

          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMary_Kawena_Pukui_and_Samuel_Hoyt_Elbert2003">
            <a href="/wiki/Mary_Kawena_Pukui" title="Mary Kawena Pukui">
             Mary Kawena Pukui
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Hoyt_Elbert" title="Samuel Hoyt Elbert">
             Samuel Hoyt Elbert
            </a>
            (2003).
            <a class="external text" href="http://wehewehe.org/gsdl2.85/cgi-bin/hdict?a=q&amp;j=pk&amp;l=en&amp;q=%26%23x02BB%3B%C5%8Dlelo&amp;a=d&amp;d=D15294" rel="nofollow">
             "lookup of
             <i>
              ʻōlelo
             </i>

             in Hawaiian Dictionary

          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFFishman1977">
            Fishman, Joshua A. (1977). "
            <span class="cs1-kern-left">
             "
            </span>
            Standard" versus "Dialect" in Bilingual Education: An Old Problem in a New Context".
            <i>
             The Modern Language Journal
            </i>
            .
            <b>
             61
            </b>
            (7): 315–325.
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">
             doi
            </a>
            :
            <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1111%2Fj.1540-4781.1977.tb05146.x" rel="nofollow">
             10.1111/j.1540-4781.1977.tb05146.x
            </a>
            .
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">
             ISSN
            </a>
            <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0026-7902" rel="nofollow">
             0026-7902
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Modern+Language+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=%22Standard%22+versus+%22Dialect%22+in+Bilingual+Education%3A+An+Old+Problem+in+a+New+Context&amp;rft.volume=61&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.pages=315-325&amp;rft.date=1977&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1111%2Fj.1540-4781.1977.tb05146.x&amp;rft.issn=0026-7902&amp;rft.aulast=Fishman&amp;rft.aufirst=Joshua+A.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-:7-9">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-:7_9-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>

          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHaertig1972">
            Haertig, E.W. (1972).
            <i>
             Nana i Ke Kumu Vol 2
            </i>
            .
            <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hui_Hanai&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hui Hanai (page does not exist)">
             Hui Hanai
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Nana+i+Ke+Kumu+Vol+2&amp;rft.pub=Hui+Hanai&amp;rft.date=1972&amp;rft.aulast=Haertig&amp;rft.aufirst=E.W.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Princeton_Library-10">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Princeton_Library_10-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation web cs1">
            <a class="external text" href="https://library.princeton.edu/visual_materials/maps/websites/pacific/cook3/map-pacific-north-mann-1781.jpg" rel="nofollow">
             "Carte de l'OCÉAN PACIFIQUE au Nord de l'équateur / Charte des STILLEN WELTMEERS nördlichen des Äequators"
            </a>
            [Chart of the PACIFIC OCEAN north of the Equator]
            <span class="cs1-format">
             (JPG)
            </span>
            .
            <i>
             Princeton University Library
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              2020-10-26
             </span>
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Princeton+University+Library&amp;rft.atitle=Carte+de+l%27OC%C3%89AN+PACIFIQUE+au+Nord+de+l%27%C3%A9quateur+%2F+Charte+des+STILLEN+WELTMEERS+n%C3%B6rdlichen+des+%C3%84equators&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Flibrary.princeton.edu%2Fvisual_materials%2Fmaps%2Fwebsites%2Fpacific%2Fcook3%2Fmap-pacific-north-mann-1781.jpg&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">
           </span>
           <br/>
           <b>
            French
           </b>
           : Carte de l'OCÉAN PACIFIQUE au Nord de l'équateur, et des côtes qui le bornent des deux cotes: d'après les dernières découvertes faites par les Espagnols, les Russes et les Anglais jusqu'en 1780.
           <br/>
           <b>
            German
           </b>
           : Charte des STILLEN WELTMEERS nördlichen des Äequators und der Küsten, die es auf beiden Seiten einschränken: Nach den neuesten, von der Spanier, Russen und Engländer bis 1780.
           <br/>
           <b>
            English
           </b>
           (translation): Chart of the PACIFIC OCEAN north of the Equator and the Coasts that bound it on both sides: according to the latest discoveries made by the Spaniards, Russians and English up to 1780.
          </span>
         </li>

          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-27">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-27">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           The
           <a href="/wiki/Proto-Austronesian_language" title="Proto-Austronesian language">
            Proto-Austronesian
           </a>
           (PAN) forms are from
           <a href="#CITEREFLi2004">
            Li (2004
           </a>
           :4).  The Tagalog forms are from
           <a href="#CITEREFRamos1971">
            Ramos (1971)
           </a>
           , the Tongan from
           <a href="#CITEREFChurchward1959">
            Churchward (1959)
           </a>
           , and the Hawaiian from
           <a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">
            Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986)
           </a>
           .
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-:2-28">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-:2_28-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-:2_28-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">
            Schütz (1994
           </a>
           :333)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-29">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-29">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFLyovin1997">
            Lyovin (1997
           </a>
           :8–12)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-30">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-30">
             ^

             ^

           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation news cs1">
