         <li id="cite_note-Lyovin_1997_259-75">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

           </a>
           :27, 31–32)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-78">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-78">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">

            Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986
           </a>
           :406)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-79">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-79">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">
            Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986
           </a>
           :450)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-80">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-80">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">
            Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986
           </a>
           :257, 281, 451)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-81">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-81">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">
            Schütz (1994
           </a>
           :146)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-82">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-82">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">
            Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979
           </a>
           :11)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-83">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-83">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFPukuiElbert1986">
            Pukui &amp; Elbert (1986
           </a>
           :62, 275)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-84">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-84">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           In English, the glottal stop is usually either omitted, or is replaced by a non-phonemic glide, resulting in
           <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
            [hʌˈwai.i]
           </span>
           or
           <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
            [hʌˈwai.ji]
           </span>
           , and
           <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
            [oˈa.hu]
           </span>
           or
           <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
            [oˈwa.hu]
           </span>
           . Note that the latter two are essentially identical in sound.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-:0-85">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-:0_85-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-:0_85-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">
            Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979
           </a>
           :10, 14, 58)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-86">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-86">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">
            Schütz (1994
           </a>
           :143)
          </span>
         </li>

          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">

           </a>
           :11)
          </span>
         </li>

          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

            Schütz (1994
           </a>
           :144–145)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Schütz_1994_139-141-89">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-Schütz_1994_139-141_89-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Schütz_1994_139-141_89-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFSchütz1994">
            Schütz (1994
           </a>
           :139–141)
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-90">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-90">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation web cs1">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.hawaiipropertytax.com/" rel="nofollow">
             "Hawaii County Real Property Tax Office"
            </a>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              2009-03-03
             </span>
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             This site was designed to provide quick and easy access to real property tax assessment records and maps for properties located in the County of Hawaiʻi and related general information about real property tax procedures.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Hawaii+County+Real+Property+Tax+Office&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hawaiipropertytax.com%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-91">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-91">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation web cs1">
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090302152356/http://pipwerks.com/journal/2009/02/22/hawaiian-diacriticals/" rel="nofollow">
             "Hawaiian diacriticals"
            </a>
            . Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="http://pipwerks.com/journal/2009/02/22/hawaiian-diacriticals/" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 2009-03-02
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              2009-03-03
             </span>
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Over the last decade, there has been an attempt by many well-meaning locals (Hawaiian and non-Hawaiian) to use substitute characters when true diacriticals aren't available. ... This brings me to one of my pet peeves and the purpose of this post: misuse of the backtick (`) character. Many of the previously-mentioned well-intentioned folks mistakenly use a backtick to represent an ʻokina, and it drives me absolutely bonkers.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Hawaiian+diacriticals&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fpipwerks.com%2Fjournal%2F2009%2F02%2F22%2Fhawaiian-diacriticals%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-92">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-92">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation web cs1">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.permaculture-hawaii.com/" rel="nofollow">
             "Laʻakea Community"
            </a>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              2009-03-03
             </span>
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Laʻakea Community formed in 2005 when a group of six people purchased Laʻakea Gardens.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=La%CA%BBakea+Community&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.permaculture-hawaii.com%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>

          <span class="reference-text">
           <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
           <cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFParker_Jones2018">
            Parker Jones, ʻŌiwi (April 2018).
            <a class="external text" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-the-international-phonetic-association/article/hawaiian/9F2B300BCF6EE97EA7E4437C5FCECB57" rel="nofollow">
             "Hawaiian"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Journal of the International Phonetic Association
            </i>
            .
            <b>
             48
            </b>
            (1): 103–115.
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">
             doi
            </a>
            :
            <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FS0025100316000438" rel="nofollow">
             10.1017/S0025100316000438
            </a>
            .
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">
             ISSN
            </a>
            <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0025-1003" rel="nofollow">
             0025-1003
            </a>
            .
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">
             S2CID
            </a>
            <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:232350292" rel="nofollow">
             232350292
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+International+Phonetic+Association&amp;rft.atitle=Hawaiian&amp;rft.volume=48&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=103-115&amp;rft.date=2018-04&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A232350292%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=0025-1003&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS0025100316000438&amp;rft.aulast=Parker+Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=%CA%BB%C5%8Ciwi&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cambridge.org%2Fcore%2Fjournals%2Fjournal-of-the-international-phonetic-association%2Farticle%2Fhawaiian%2F9F2B300BCF6EE97EA7E4437C5FCECB57&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">

         <li id="cite_note-:6-120">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-:6_120-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-:6_120-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Wong, L. (1999). Authenticity and the Revitalization of Hawaiian.
           <i>
            Anthropology &amp; Education Quarterly,
           </i>
           <i>
            30
           </i>
           (1), 94-115.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-121">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-121">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Grenoble, Lenore A. (2012). Austin, Peter (ed.). "The Cambridge Handbook of Endangered Languages". Cambridge University Press.
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">
            doi
           </a>
           :10.1017/cbo9780511975981.002. Retrieved 2020-12-08.
          </span>
         </li>
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
        <cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFParker_Jones2009">
         Parker Jones, ʻŌiwi (2009).
         <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100209071913/http://wold.livingsources.org/vocabulary/30" rel="nofollow">
          "Loanwords in Hawaiian"
         </a>
         .  In Haspelmath, M.; Tadmor, U. (eds.).
         <a class="external text" href="http://wold.livingsources.org/vocabulary/30" rel="nofollow">
          <i>
           Loanwords in the World's Languages: A Comparative Handbook
          </i>
         </a>
         . Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. pp. 771–789.
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">
          ISBN
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-11-021843-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-11-021843-5">
          <bdi>
           978-3-11-021843-5
          </bdi>
         </a>
         . Archived from
         <a class="external text" href="https://www.academia.edu/3769002" rel="nofollow">
          the original
         </a>
         on 2010-02-09.
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Loanwords+in+Hawaiian&amp;rft.btitle=Loanwords+in+the+World%27s+Languages%3A+A+Comparative+Handbook&amp;rft.place=Berlin&amp;rft.pages=771-789&amp;rft.pub=Mouton+de+Gruyter&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-11-021843-5&amp;rft.aulast=Parker+Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=%CA%BB%C5%8Ciwi&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.academia.edu%2F3769002&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
        <cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFParker_Jones2018">
         Parker Jones, ʻŌiwi (2018).
         <a class="external text" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-the-international-phonetic-association/article/hawaiian/9F2B300BCF6EE97EA7E4437C5FCECB57" rel="nofollow">
          "Hawaiian"
         </a>
         .
         <i>
          Journal of the International Phonetic Association
         </i>
         .
         <b>
          48
         </b>
         (1): 103–115.
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">
          doi
         </a>
         :
         <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FS0025100316000438" rel="nofollow">
          10.1017/S0025100316000438
         </a>
         .
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">

         <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:232350292" rel="nofollow">
          232350292
         </a>
         .
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+International+Phonetic+Association&amp;rft.atitle=Hawaiian&amp;rft.volume=48&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=103-115&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS0025100316000438&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A232350292%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Parker+Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=%CA%BB%C5%8Ciwi&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cambridge.org%2Fcore%2Fjournals%2Fjournal-of-the-international-phonetic-association%2Farticle%2Fhawaiian%2F9F2B300BCF6EE97EA7E4437C5FCECB57&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHawaiian+language">
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>

        <cite class="citation thesis cs1" id="CITEREFWarner1996">
         Warner, Sam L. (1996).
         <i>
          I Ola ka ʻŌlelo i nā Keiki: Ka ʻApo ʻia ʻana o ka ʻŌlelo Hawaiʻi e nā Keiki ma ke Kula Kaiapuni. [That the Language Live through the Children: The Acquisition of the Hawaiian Language by the Children in the Immersion School.]

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">
        External links
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">

         [
        </span>

        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>

      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://niuolahiki.ahapunanaleo.org" rel="nofollow">
         Niuolahiki Distance Learning Program
        </a>
        (a moodle-based online study program for Hawaiian)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061203064044/http://ulukau.org/english.php" rel="nofollow">
         Ulukau – the Hawaiian electronic library
        </a>
        , includes English to/from Hawaiian dictionary
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.nupepa.org/" rel="nofollow">
         digitized Hawaiian language newspapers published between 1834 and 1948
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://wold.clld.org/vocabulary/30" rel="nofollow">
         Hawaiian Vocabulary List
        </a>
        (from the World Loanword Database)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.olelo.hawaii.edu/dual/orgs/keelikolani/" rel="nofollow">
         Ka Haka ʻUla O Keʻelikōlani, College of Hawaiian Language
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://ksdl.ksbe.edu/kulaiwi/" rel="nofollow">
         Kulaiwi
        </a>
        – learn Hawaiian through distance learning courses
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.hawaiian.saivus.org/" rel="nofollow">
         Hawaiian.saivus.org
        </a>
        – Detailed Hawaiian Language Pronunciation Guide
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160124232335/http://www.traditionalhawaiian.com/" rel="nofollow">
         Traditional and Neo Hawaiian: The Emergence of a New Form of Hawaiian Language as a Result of Hawaiian Language Regeneration
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100531191931/http://www.mauimagazine.net/Maui-Magazine/May-June-2008/Hale-Pai/" rel="nofollow">
         "Hale Pa'i"
        </a>
        Article about Hawaiian language newspapers printed at
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lahainaluna" title="Lahainaluna">
         Lahainaluna
        </a>
        on
        <a href="/wiki/Maui" title="Maui">
         Maui
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maui_No_Ka_%27Oi_Magazine" title="Maui No Ka 'Oi Magazine">
          Maui No Ka 'Oi Magazine
         </a>
        </i>
        Vol.12 No.3 (May 2008).
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.hawaiimagazine.com/blogs/hawaii_today/2010/5/12/new_iPhone_apps_help_speak_Hawaiian/" rel="nofollow">
         "Speak Hawaiian"'
        </a>
        Article about Hawaiian language resource on iPhone.  (May 2010).
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.friesian.com/hawaii.htm#pronounce" rel="nofollow">
         How to Pronounce "Hawai'i"
        </a>
        , Kelley L. Ross, Ph.D, 2008
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20111228042423/http://www.language-archives.org/language/haw" rel="nofollow">
         OLAC Resources in and about the Hawaiian language
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/March-2012/Best-of-Honolulu-2012/Best-of-Honolulu-2012-Services/" rel="nofollow">
         "
        </a>
        Article about Hawaiian Dictionary resource on iPhone in Honolulu Magazine.  (May 2012).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <div class="navbox-styles nomobile">
       <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1057682214">

          </td>
         </tr>

            </a>
            <a href="https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q33569#identifiers" title="Edit this at Wikidata">
             <img alt="Edit this at Wikidata" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="10" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/10px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/15px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/20px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png 2x" style="vertical-align: text-top" width="10"/>
            </a>
           </div>
          </th>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">
           General
          </th>
          <td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0">
           <div style="padding:0 0.25em">
            <ul>
             <li>
              <span class="uid">
               <a class="external text" href="https://d-nb.info/gnd/4159314-5" rel="nofollow">
                Integrated Authority File (Germany)
               </a>
              </span>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </div>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">

    <nav aria-labelledby="p-coll-print_export-label" class="mw-portlet mw-portlet-coll-print_export vector-menu vector-menu-portal portal" id="p-coll-print_export" role="navigation">
     <h3 aria-label="" class="vector-menu-heading" id="p-coll-print_export-label">
      <span class="vector-menu-heading-label">
       Print/export
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="vector-menu-content">

<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading">Hawaiian language</h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Polynesian language</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1048617464">.mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .infobox-3cols-child{margin:auto}</style><table class="infobox vevent"><tbody><tr><th class="infobox-above above" colspan="2" style="font-size:125%; color: black; background-color: pink;">Hawaiian</th></tr><tr><td class="infobox-subheader" colspan="2" style="font-size:110%; color: black; background-color: pink;"><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">ʻŌlelo Hawaiʻi</i></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Native to</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands" title="Hawaiian Islands">Hawaiian Islands</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Region</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a href="/wiki/Hawaii_(island)" title="Hawaii (island)">Hawaiʻi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Niihau" title="Niihau">Niʻihau</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a href="/wiki/Native_Hawaiians" title="Native Hawaiians">Native Hawaiians</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Native speakers</div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;">~24,000 (2008)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;"><span class="wrap"><a href="/wiki/Language_family" title="Language family">Language family</a></span></div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><div style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian</a>
<ul style="line-height:100%; margin-left:1.35em;padding-left:0"><li>

<ul style="line-height:100%; margin-left:1.35em; padding-left:0"><li><a href="/wiki/Proto-Malayo-Polynesian_language" title="Proto-Malayo-Polynesian language">Proto-Malayo-Polynesian</a>
<ul style="line-height:100%; margin-left:0.45em; padding-left:0"><li><a href="/wiki/Proto-Oceanic_language" title="Proto-Oceanic language">Proto-Oceanic</a>
<ul style="line-height:100%; margin-left:0.45em; padding-left:0"><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Polynesian" title="Proto-Polynesian">Proto-Polynesian</a>
</li></ul>
</li></ul>
</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr class="plainlist"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Dialects</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;">
<ul><li>Standard Hawaiian</li>

<li>Other dialects</li></ul>
</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;"><span class="wrap"><a href="/wiki/Writing_system" title="Writing system">Writing system</a></span></div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Latin_script" title="Latin script">Latin</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_alphabet" title="Hawaiian alphabet">Hawaiian alphabet</a>)</li><li><a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Braille" title="Hawaiian Braille">Hawaiian Braille</a></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;"><span class="wrap"><a href="/wiki/Manually_coded_language" title="Manually coded language">Signed forms</a></span></div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hawai%27i_Sign_Language" title="Hawai'i Sign Language">Hawaiʻi Sign Language (HSL)</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-header" colspan="2" style="color: black; background-color: pink;">Official status</th></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Official language in</div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="1235" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a><br/>
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Flag_of_Hawaii.svg/23px-Flag_of_Hawaii.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Flag_of_Hawaii.svg/35px-Flag_of_Hawaii.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Flag_of_Hawaii.svg/46px-Flag_of_Hawaii.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a></li></ul>
</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-header" colspan="2" style="color: black; background-color: pink;">Language codes</th></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/ISO_639-2" title="ISO 639-2">ISO 639-2</a></span></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><code><span class="plainlinks"><a class="external text" href="https://www.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/php/langcodes_name.php?code_ID=183" rel="nofollow">haw</a></span></code></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/ISO_639-3" title="ISO 639-3">ISO 639-3</a></span></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><code><a class="extiw" href="https://iso639-3.sil.org/code/haw" title="iso639-3:haw">haw</a></code></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><a href="/wiki/Glottolog" title="Glottolog">Glottolog</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><code><a class="external text" href="http://glottolog.org/resource/languoid/id/hawa1245" rel="nofollow">hawa1245</a></code></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><a href="/wiki/Endangered_Languages_Project" title="Endangered Languages Project">ELP</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a class="external text" href="http://www.endangeredlanguages.com/lang/125" rel="nofollow">Hawaiian</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><a href="/wiki/Linguasphere_Observatory" title="Linguasphere Observatory">Linguasphere</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><code>39-CAQ-e</code></td></tr><tr><td class="infobox-below noprint selfref" colspan="2" style="background-color:#E7E7FF;padding:0.3em 0.5em;text-align:left;line-height:1.3;"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">IPA</a> phonetic symbols.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA#Rendering_issues" title="Help:IPA">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a> instead of <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> characters. For an introductory guide on IPA symbols, see <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">Help:IPA</a>.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Hawaiian</b> (<i><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">ʻŌlelo Hawaiʻi</i></i>, <small>pronounced </small><span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Hawaiian" title="Help:IPA/Hawaiian">[ʔoːˈlɛlo həˈvɐjʔi]</a></span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polynesian_language" title="Polynesian language">Polynesian language</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austronesian_language_family" title="Austronesian language family">Austronesian language family</a> that takes its name from <a href="/wiki/Hawaii_(island)" title="Hawaii (island)">Hawaiʻi</a>, the largest island in the tropical North Pacific <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> where it developed. Hawaiian, along with <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, is an official language of the <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">US state of Hawaii</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Article_XV,_Section_4_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-Article_XV,_Section_4-3">[3]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kamehameha_III" title="Kamehameha III">King Kamehameha III</a> established the first Hawaiian-language <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">constitution</a> in 1839 and 1840.
</p><p>For various reasons, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hawaii_Territory" title="Hawaii Territory">territorial</a> legislation establishing English as the official language in schools, the number of <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">native speakers</a> of Hawaiian gradually decreased during the period from the 1830s to the 1950s. Hawaiian was essentially displaced by English on six of seven inhabited islands. In 2001, native speakers of Hawaiian amounted to less than 0.1% of the statewide population. Linguists were unsure if Hawaiian and other <a href="/wiki/Endangered_language" title="Endangered language">endangered languages</a> would survive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="Source does not mention linguists or Hawaiian language (January 2020)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Nevertheless, from around 1949 to the present day, there has been a gradual increase in attention to and promotion of the language. Public Hawaiian-language immersion preschools called <a href="/wiki/P%C5%ABnana_Leo" title="Pūnana Leo">Pūnana Leo</a> were established in 1984; other immersion schools followed soon after that. The first students to start in immersion preschool have now graduated from college and many are fluent Hawaiian speakers. The federal government has acknowledged this development. For example, the Hawaiian National Park Language Correction Act of 2000 changed the names of several <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national parks</a> in Hawaiʻi, observing the Hawaiian spelling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> However, the language is still classified as critically endangered by UNESCO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Creole_language" title="Creole language">creole language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Pidgin" title="Hawaiian Pidgin">Hawaiian Pidgin</a> (or Hawaii Creole English, HCE), is more commonly spoken in Hawaiʻi than Hawaiian. Some linguists, as well as many locals, argue that Hawaiian Pidgin is a <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">dialect</a> of American English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Born from the increase of immigrants from Japan, China, Puerto Rico, Korea, Portugal, Spain and the Philippines, the pidgin creole language was a necessity in the plantations. Hawaiian and immigrant laborers as well as the white <i>luna,</i> or overseers, found a way to communicate amongst themselves. Pidgin eventually made its way off the plantation and into the greater community, where it is still used to this day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-:7-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_alphabet" title="Hawaiian alphabet">Hawaiian alphabet</a> has 13 letters: five vowels: a e i o u (each with a long pronunciation and a short one) and eight consonants: he ke la mu nu pi we, including a glottal stop called <a href="#Glottal_stop">ʻokina</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Name"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Name</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Family_and_origin"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Family and origin</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Methods_of_proving_Hawaiian's_linguistic_relationships"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Methods of proving Hawaiian's linguistic relationships</span></a></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Name">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The Hawaiian language takes its name from the largest island in the Hawaiian state, <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a> (<i><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">Hawaiʻi</i></i> in the Hawaiian language). The island name was first written in English in 1778 by British explorer <a href="/wiki/James_Cook" title="James Cook">James Cook</a> and his crew members. They wrote it as "Owhyhee" or "Owhyee". It is written "Oh-Why-hee" on the first map of Sandwich Islands engraved by <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Tobias_Conrad_Lotter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Tobias Conrad Lotter (page does not exist)">Tobias Conrad Lotter</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;"> [<a class="extiw" href="https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobias_Conrad_Lotter" title="de:Tobias Conrad Lotter">de</a>]</span> in 1781.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Princeton_Library_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-Princeton_Library-10">[10]</a></sup> Explorers Mortimer (1791) and <a href="/wiki/Otto_von_Kotzebue" title="Otto von Kotzebue">Otto von Kotzebue</a> (1821) used that spelling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>The initial "O" in the name is a reflection of the fact that Hawaiian predicates unique identity by using a <a href="/wiki/Copula_(linguistics)" title="Copula (linguistics)">copula</a> form, <i>o</i>, immediately before a proper noun.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> Thus, in Hawaiian, the name of the island is expressed by saying <i><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">O Hawaiʻi</i></i>, which means "[This] is Hawaiʻi."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> The Cook expedition also wrote "Otaheite" rather than "Tahiti."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>The spelling "why" in the name reflects the <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[hw]</span> pronunciation of <i>wh</i> in 18th-century English (still <a href="/wiki/Pronunciation_of_English_%E2%9F%A8wh%E2%9F%A9" title="Pronunciation of English ⟨wh⟩">used</a> in parts of the <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">English-speaking world</a>). <i>Why</i> was pronounced <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[hwai]</span>. The spelling "hee" or "ee" in the name represents the sounds <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[hi]</span>, or <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[i]</span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>Putting the parts together, <i>O-why-(h)ee</i> reflects <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[o-hwai-i]</span>, a reasonable approximation of the native pronunciation, <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[o hɐwɐiʔi]</span>.
</p><p>American missionaries bound for Hawaiʻi used the phrases "Owhihe Language" and "Owhyhee language" in Boston prior to their departure in October 1819 and during their five-month voyage to Hawaiʻi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> They still used such phrases as late as March 1822.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> However, by July 1823, they had begun using the phrase "Hawaiian Language."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Hawaiian, the language is called <i><i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">ʻŌlelo Hawaiʻi</i></i>, since adjectives follow nouns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family_and_origin">Family and origin</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Family and origin">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Hawaiian is a Polynesian member of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian language family</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> It is closely related to other <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_languages" title="Polynesian languages">Polynesian languages</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Samoan_language" title="Samoan language">Samoan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marquesan_language" title="Marquesan language">Marquesan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tahitian_language" title="Tahitian language">Tahitian</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language" title="Māori language">Māori</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rapa_Nui_language" title="Rapa Nui language">Rapa Nui</a> (the language of <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Tongan_language" title="Tongan language">Tongan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>
According to Schütz (1994), the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Marquesas_Islands" title="Culture of the Marquesas Islands">Marquesans</a> colonized the archipelago in roughly 300 CE<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> followed by later waves of immigration from the <a href="/wiki/Society_Islands" title="Society Islands">Society Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samoa" title="Samoa">Samoa</a>-<a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a>. Their languages, over time, became the Hawaiian language within the Hawaiian Islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Kimura and Wilson (1983) also state: </p><blockquote><p>Linguists agree that Hawaiian is closely related to Eastern Polynesian, with a particularly strong link in the Southern Marquesas, and a secondary link in Tahiti, which may be explained by voyaging between the Hawaiian and Society Islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h3><span id="Methods_of_proving_Hawaiian.27s_linguistic_relationships"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Methods_of_proving_Hawaiian's_linguistic_relationships">Methods of proving Hawaiian's linguistic relationships</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Methods of proving Hawaiian's linguistic relationships">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Genetic_relationship_(linguistics)" title="Genetic relationship (linguistics)">genetic</a> history of the Hawaiian language is demonstrated primarily through the application of <a href="/wiki/Lexicostatistics" title="Lexicostatistics">lexicostatistics</a>, which involves quantitative comparison of lexical <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cognates" title="Cognates">cognates</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Comparative_method" title="Comparative method">comparative method</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lyovin1_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-lyovin1-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Both the number of cognates and the phonological similarity of cognates are measures of language relationship.
</p><p>The following table provides a limited lexicostatistical data set for ten numbers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> The asterisk (*) is used to show that these are hypothetical, <a href="/wiki/Linguistic_reconstruction" title="Linguistic reconstruction">reconstructed</a> forms. In the table, the year date of the modern forms is rounded off to 2000 CE to emphasize the 6000-year time lapse since the PAN era.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p><span class="anchor" id="Numbers"></span>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible">
<caption>Numbers in <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian languages</a>
</caption>

</td>

</td>
<td align="center">toru
</td>
<td align="center">whā
</td>
<td align="center">rima
</td>
<td align="center">ono
</td>
<td align="center">whitu
</td>
<td align="center">waru
</td>
<td align="center">iwa
</td>
<td align="center">tekau (<span style="font-size:85%;">archaic:</span> ngahuru)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><a href="/wiki/Tahitian_language" title="Tahitian language">Tahitian</a>
</th>
<td align="center">hō'ē
</td>
<td align="center">piti
</td>
<td align="center">toru
</td>
<td align="center">maha
</td>
<td align="center">pae
</td>
<td align="center">ōno
</td>
<td align="center">hitu
</td>
<td align="center">va'u
</td>
<td align="center">iva
</td>
<td align="center">'ahuru
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><a href="/wiki/Marquesan_language" title="Marquesan language">Marquesan</a>
</th>
<td align="center">tahi
</td>
<td align="center">'ua
</td>
<td align="center">to'u
</td>
<td align="center">hā
</td>
<td align="center">'ima
</td>
<td align="center">ono
</td>
<td align="center">hitu
</td>
<td align="center">va'u
</td>
<td align="center">iva
</td>
<td align="center">'ahu'u
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><a href="/wiki/Leeward_Islands_(Society_Islands)" title="Leeward Islands (Society Islands)">Leeward Islands</a> dialect
</th>
<td align="center">tahi
</td>
<td align="center">rua
</td>
<td align="center">toru
</td>
<td align="center">fā
</td>
<td align="center">rima
</td>
<td align="center">ono
</td>
<td align="center">fitu
</td>
<td align="center">varu
</td>
<td align="center">iva
</td>
<td align="center">'ahuru
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands_M%C4%81ori" title="Cook Islands Māori">Cook Islands Māori</a>
</th>
<td align="center">ta'i
</td>
<td align="center">rua
</td>
<td align="center">toru
</td>
<td align="center">ā
</td>
<td align="center">rima
</td>
<td align="center">ono
</td>
<td align="center">itu
</td>
<td align="center">varu
</td>
<td align="center">iva
</td>
<td align="center">ta'ingaoru
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><strong>Hawaiian</strong>
</th>
<td align="center">ʻekahi
</td>
<td align="center">ʻelua
</td>
<td align="center">ʻekolu
</td>
<td align="center">ʻehā
</td>
<td align="center">ʻelima
</td>
<td align="center">ʻeono
</td>
<td align="center">ʻehiku
</td>
<td align="center">ʻewalu
</td>
<td align="center">ʻeiwa
</td>
<td align="center">-ʻumi
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Note: For the number "10", the Tongan form in the table is part of the word <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/hoŋo-fulu/</span> ('ten'). The Hawaiian cognate is part of the word <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/ana-hulu/</span> ('ten days'); however, the more common word for "10" used in counting and quantifying is <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/ʔumi/</span>, a different root.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Application of the lexicostatistical method to the data in the table will show the four languages to be related to one another, with Tagalog having 100% cognacy with PAN, while Hawaiian and Tongan have 100% cognacy with each other, but 90% with Tagalog and PAN. This is because the forms for each number are cognates, except the Hawaiian and Tongan words for the number "1", which are cognate with each other, but not with Tagalog and PAN. When the full set of 200 meanings is used, the percentages will be much lower. For example, Elbert found Hawaiian and Tongan to have 49% (98 ÷ 200) shared cognacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-28">[28]</a></sup> This points out the importance of data-set size for this method, where less data leads to cruder results, while more data leads to better results.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-28">[28]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Application of the comparative method will show partly different genetic relationships. It will point out <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sound_changes" title="Sound changes">sound changes</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> such as:
</p>
<ol><li>the loss of all PAN word-final consonants in Tongan and Hawaiian;</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raising_(phonetics)#Raised_and_lowered_vowels" title="Raising (phonetics)">lowering</a> of PAN <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">*u</span> to Tagalog <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[o]</span> in word-final syllables;</li>
<li>retention of PAN <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">*t</span> in word-initial and word-medial position in Tagalog and Tongan, but shift to <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/k/</span> in Hawaiian;</li>
<li>retention of PAN <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">*p</span> in Tagalog, but shift to <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/f/</span> in Tongan and <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/h/</span> in Hawaiian.</li></ol>
<p>This method will recognize sound change #1 as a <a href="/wiki/Comparative_method#Demonstrating_genetic_relationship" title="Comparative method">shared innovation</a> of Hawaiian and Tongan. It will also take the Hawaiian and Tongan cognates for "1" as another shared innovation. Due to these exclusively shared features, Hawaiian and Tongan are found to be more closely related to one another than either is to Tagalog or Amis.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The forms in the table show that the Austronesian vowels tend to be relatively stable, while the consonants are relatively volatile. It is also apparent that the Hawaiian words for "3", "5", and "8" have remained essentially unchanged for 6000 years.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mutual_intelligibility">Mutual intelligibility</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Mutual intelligibility">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Jack H. Ward (1962) conducted a study using basic words and short utterances to determine the level of comprehension between different Polynesian languages. The mutual intelligibility of Hawaiian was found to be 41.2% with Marquesan, 37.5% with Tahitian, 25.5% with Samoan and 6.4% with Tongan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For Hawaiian language history before 1778, see <a href="#Family_and_origin">§ Family and origin</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_European_contact">First European contact</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: First European contact">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1778, British explorer James Cook made Europe's initial, recorded <a href="/wiki/First_contact_(anthropology)" title="First contact (anthropology)">first contact</a> with Hawaiʻi, beginning a new phase in the development of Hawaiian. During the next forty years, the sounds of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> (1789), <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> (1804), <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> (1816), and <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a> (1816) arrived in Hawaiʻi via other explorers and businessmen. Hawaiian began to be written for the first time, largely restricted to isolated names and words, and word lists collected by explorers and travelers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>The early explorers and merchants who first brought European languages to the Hawaiian islands also took on a few native crew members who brought the Hawaiian language into new territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Hawaiians took these nautical jobs because their traditional way of life changed due to plantations, and although there were not enough of these Hawaiian-speaking explorers to establish any viable speech communities abroad, they still had a noticeable presence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> One of them, a boy in his teens known as <a href="/wiki/Henry_Opukahaia" title="Henry Opukahaia">Obookiah</a> (<i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">ʻŌpūkahaʻia</i>), had a major impact on the future of the language. He sailed to <a href="/wiki/New_England" title="New England">New England</a>, where he eventually became a student at the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Mission_School" title="Foreign Mission School">Foreign Mission School</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cornwall,_Connecticut" title="Cornwall, Connecticut">Cornwall, Connecticut</a>. He inspired New Englanders to support a Christian mission to Hawaiʻi, and provided information on the Hawaiian language to the American missionaries there prior to their departure for Hawaiʻi in 1819.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Adelbert_von_Chamisso" title="Adelbert von Chamisso">Adelbert von Chamisso</a> too might have consulted with a native speaker of Hawaiian in Berlin, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, before publishing his grammar of Hawaiian (<i><i lang="de" title="German-language text">Über die Hawaiische Sprache</i></i>) in 1837.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Folk_tales">Folk tales</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Folk tales">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Like all natural spoken languages, the Hawaiian language was originally just an oral language. The native people of the Hawaiian language relayed religion, traditions, history, and views of their world through stories that were handed down from generation to generation. One form of storytelling most commonly associated with the Hawaiian islands is <a href="/wiki/Hula" title="Hula">hula</a>. Nathaniel B. Emerson notes that "It kept the communal imagination in living touch with the nation's legendary past".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>The islanders' connection with their stories is argued to be one reason why Captain James Cook received a pleasant welcome. Marshall Sahlins has observed that Hawaiian folktales began bearing similar content to those of the Western world in the eighteenth century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> He argues this was caused by the timing of Captain Cook's arrival, which was coincidentally when the indigenous Hawaiians were celebrating the Makahiki festival, which is the annual celebration of the harvest in honor of the god Lono. The celebration lasts for the entirety of the “rainy season”. It is a time of peace with much emphasis on amusements, food, games, and dancing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> The islanders' story foretold of the god Lono's return at the time of the Makahiki festival.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> The arrival of Captain Cook on the Endeavor with its massive white sails, unlike anything any Hawaiians had ever seen, seemed like the god Lono arriving on his floating island with white flags as it had been foretold.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-:7-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Written_Hawaiian">Written Hawaiian</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Written Hawaiian">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1820, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Missionaries" title="Missionaries">missionaries</a> from <a href="/wiki/New_England" title="New England">New England</a> arrived in Hawaiʻi, and in a few years converted the chiefs to <a href="/wiki/Congregational_church" title="Congregational church">Congregational</a> Protestantism, who in turn converted their subjects. To the missionaries, the thorough Christianization of the kingdom necessitated a complete translation of the Bible to Hawaiian, a previously unwritten language, and therefore the creation of a standard spelling that should be as easy to master as possible. The orthography created by the missionaries was so straightforward that literacy spread very quickly among the adult population; at the same time, the Mission set more and more schools for children. 
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="836" data-file-width="938" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif/220px-Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif/330px-Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif/440px-Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ka_Lama_Hawaii.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Headline from May 16, 1834, issue of newspaper published by <a href="/wiki/Lorrin_Andrews" title="Lorrin Andrews">Lorrin Andrews</a> and students at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lahainaluna" title="Lahainaluna">Lahainaluna</a> School</div></div></div>
<p>In 1834, the first Hawaiian-language newspapers were published by missionaries working with locals. The missionaries also played a significant role in publishing a vocabulary (1836)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> grammar (1854)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> and dictionary (1865)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> of Hawaiian. The Hawaiian Bible was fully completed in 1839; by then, the Mission had such a wide-reaching school network that, when in 1840 it handed it over to the Hawaiian government, the Hawaiian Legislature mandated compulsory state-funded education for all children under 14 years of age, including girls, twelve years before any similar <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education#United_States" title="Compulsory education">compulsory education</a> law was enacted for the first time in any of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>Literacy in Hawaiian was so widespread that in 1842 a law mandated that people born after 1819 had to be literate to be allowed to marry. In his <i>Report to the Legislature</i> for the year 1853 <a href="/wiki/Richard_Armstrong_(Hawaii_missionary)" title="Richard Armstrong (Hawaii missionary)">Richard Armstrong</a>, the minister of Public Instruction, bragged that 75% of the adult population could read. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Use of the language among the general population might have peaked around 1881. Even so, some people worried, as early as 1854, that the language was "soon destined to extinction."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>When Hawaiian King <a href="/wiki/Kal%C4%81kaua" title="Kalākaua">David Kalākaua</a> took a trip around the world, he brought his native language with him. When his wife, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_Kapiolani" title="Queen Kapiolani">Queen Kapiʻolani</a>, and his sister, Princess (later Queen) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liliuokalani" title="Liliuokalani">Liliʻuokalani</a>, took a trip across North America and on to the British Islands, in 1887, Liliʻuokalani's composition <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aloha_Oe" title="Aloha Oe">Aloha ʻOe</a></i> was already a famous song in the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Suppression_of_Hawaiian">Suppression of Hawaiian</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Suppression of Hawaiian">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The decline of the Hawaiian language  was accelerated by the coup that overthrew the Hawaiian monarchy and dethroned the existing Hawaiian queen. Thereafter, a law was instituted that required English as the main language of school instruction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-47">[47]</a></sup> The law cited is identified as Act 57, sec. 30 of the 1896 Laws of the Republic of Hawaiʻi:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>The English Language shall be the medium and basis of instruction in all public and private schools, provided that where it is desired that another language shall be taught in addition to the English language, such instruction may be authorized by the Department, either by its rules, the curriculum of the school, or by direct order in any particular instance. Any schools that shall not conform to the provisions of this section shall not be recognized by the Department.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite>The Laws of Hawaii, Chapter 10, Section 123<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Congress_1898_p._1-PA23_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Congress_1898_p._1-PA23-48">[48]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>
<p>This law established English as the medium of instruction for the government-recognized schools both "public and private". While it did not ban or make illegal the Hawaiian language in other contexts, its implementation in the schools had far-reaching effects. Those who had been pushing for English-only schools took this law as licence to extinguish the native language at the early education level. While the law did not make Hawaiian illegal (it was still commonly spoken at the time), many children who spoke Hawaiian at school, including on the playground, were disciplined. This included corporal punishment and going to the home of the offending child to advise them strongly to stop speaking it in their home.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Moreover, the law specifically provided for teaching languages "in addition to the English language," reducing Hawaiian to the status of an extra language, subject to approval by the Department. Hawaiian was not taught initially in any school, including the all-Hawaiian <a href="/wiki/Kamehameha_Schools" title="Kamehameha Schools">Kamehameha Schools</a>. This is largely because when these schools were founded, like Kamehameha Schools founded in 1887 (nine years before this law), Hawaiian was being spoken in the home. Once this law was enacted, individuals at these institutions took it upon themselves to enforce a ban on Hawaiian. Beginning in 1900, Mary Kawena Pukui, who was later the co-author of the Hawaiian–English Dictionary, was punished for speaking Hawaiian by being rapped on the forehead, allowed to eat only bread and water for lunch, and denied home visits on holidays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Winona_Beamer" title="Winona Beamer">Winona Beamer</a> was expelled from Kamehameha Schools in 1937 for chanting Hawaiian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> Due in part to this systemic surpression of the language after the overthrow, Hawaiian is still considered a critically endangered language.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="319" data-file-width="567" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg/220px-Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg/330px-Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg/440px-Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Student_nationality_Hawaii_1890-1920.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>National origin of students in the schools of Hawaii (1890-1920)</div></div></div>
<p>However, informal coercion to drop Hawaiian wouldn't have worked by itself. Just as important was the fact that, in the same period, native Hawaiians were becoming a minority in their own land on account of the growing influx of foreign labourers and their children. Whereas in 1890 pure Hawaiian students made 56% of school enrollment, in 1900 their numbers were down to 32% and, in 1910, to 16.9%. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-52">[52]</a></sup> At the same time, Hawaiians were very prone to intermarriage: the number of "Part-Hawaiian" students (i.e., children of mixed Caucasian-Hawaiian marriages) grew from 1573 in 1890 to 3718 in 1910. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-:4-52">[52]</a></sup> In such mixed households, the low prestige of Hawaiian lead to the adoption of English as the family language. Moreover, Hawaiians lived mostly in the cities or scattered across the countryside, in direct contact with other ethnic groups and without any stronghold (with the exception of Niʻihau). Thus, even pure Hawaiian children would converse daily with their schoolmates of diverse mother tongues in English, which was now not just the teachers' language but also the common language needed for everyday communication among friends and neighbours out of school as well. In only a generation English (or rather Pidgin) would become the primary and dominant language of all children, despite the efforts of Hawaiian and immigrant parents to maintain their ancestral languages within the family.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1949_to_present">1949 to present</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: 1949 to present">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1949, the legislature of the Territory of Hawaiʻi commissioned Mary Pukui and Samuel Elbert to write a new dictionary of Hawaiian, either revising the Andrews-Parker work or starting from scratch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> Pukui and Elbert took a middle course, using what they could from the Andrews dictionary, but making certain improvements and additions that were more significant than a minor revision. The dictionary they produced, in 1957, introduced an era of gradual increase in attention to the language and culture.
</p><p>Language revitalization and Hawaiian culture has seen a major revival since the <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Renaissance" title="Hawaiian Renaissance">Hawaiian renaissance</a> in the 1970's. Forming in 1983, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%CA%BBAha_P%C5%ABnana_Leo" title="ʻAha Pūnana Leo">‘Aha Pūnana Leo</a>, meaning "language nest" in Hawaiian, opened its first center in 1984. It was a privately-funded Hawaiian preschool program that invited native Hawaiian elders to speak to children in Hawaiian everyday.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> Efforts to promote the language have increased in recent decades. Hawaiian-language "immersion" schools are now open to children whose families want to reintroduce Hawaiian language for future generations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/P%C5%ABnana_Leo" title="Pūnana Leo">ʻAha Pūnana Leo</a>’s Hawaiian language preschools in <a href="/wiki/Hilo,_Hawaii" title="Hilo, Hawaii">Hilo, Hawaii</a>, have received international recognition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> The local <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Public_Radio" title="National Public Radio">National Public Radio</a>  station features a short segment titled "Hawaiian word of the day" and a Hawaiian language news broadcast. <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a> television station <a href="/wiki/KGMB" title="KGMB">KGMB</a> ran a weekly Hawaiian language program, <i>ʻĀhaʻi ʻŌlelo Ola</i>, as recently as 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hawaii_News_Now_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hawaii_News_Now-57">[57]</a></sup> Additionally, the Sunday editions of the <i><a href="/wiki/Honolulu_Star-Advertiser" title="Honolulu Star-Advertiser">Honolulu Star-Advertiser</a></i>, the largest newspaper in Hawaii, feature a brief article called <i>Kauakukalahale</i> written entirely in Hawaiian by teachers, students, and community members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, the number of native speakers of Hawaiian, which was under 0.1% of the statewide population in 1997, has risen to 2,000, out of 24,000 total who are fluent in the language, according to the US 2011 census. On six of the seven permanently inhabited islands, Hawaiian has been largely displaced by English, but on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ni%CA%BBihau" title="Niʻihau">Niʻihau</a>, native speakers of Hawaiian have remained fairly isolated and have continued to use Hawaiian almost exclusively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_258_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lyovin_1997_258-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_47-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-47">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Ni.CA.BBihau"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Niʻihau">Niʻihau</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Niʻihau">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Niʻihau is the only area in the world where Hawaiian is the first language and English is a foreign language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup></p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite>Samuel Elbert and Mary Pukui, <i>Hawaiian Grammar</i> (1979)</cite></div></blockquote>
<p>The isolated island of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ni%CA%BBihau" title="Niʻihau">Niʻihau</a>, located off the southwest coast of <a href="/wiki/Kauai" title="Kauai">Kauai</a>, is the one island where Hawaiian (more specifically a local dialect of Hawaiian known as <a href="/wiki/Niihau_dialect" title="Niihau dialect">Niihau dialect</a>) is still spoken as the language of daily life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lyovin_1997_258_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lyovin_1997_258-59">[59]</a></sup>
<a href="#CITEREFElbertPukui1979">Elbert &amp; Pukui (1979</a>:23) states that "[v]ariations in Hawaiian dialects have not been systematically studied", and that "[t]he dialect of Niʻihau is the most aberrant and the one most in need of study". They recognized that Niʻihauans can speak Hawaiian in substantially different ways. Their statements are based in part on some specific observations made by <a href="#CITEREFNewbrand1951">Newbrand (1951)</a>. (See <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_phonology#Phonological_processes" title="Hawaiian phonology">Hawaiian phonological processes</a>)
</p><p>Friction has developed between those on Niʻihau that speak Hawaiian as a first language, and those who speak Hawaiian as a second language, especially those educated by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ka_Haka_%CA%BBUla_O_Ke%CA%BBelik%C5%8Dlani,_College_of_Hawaiian_Language" title="Ka Haka ʻUla O Keʻelikōlani, College of Hawaiian Language">College of Hawaiian Language</a> at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Hawai%CA%BBi_at_Hilo" title="University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo">University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo</a>. The University sponsors a Hawaiian Language Lexicon Committee (<i lang="haw" title="Hawaiian-language text">Kōmike Huaʻōlelo Hou</i>) which coins words for concepts that historically have not existed in the language, like "computer" and "cell phone". These words are generally not incorporated into the Niʻihau dialect, which often coins its own words organically. Some new words are Hawaiianized versions of English words, and some are composed of Hawaiian roots and unrelated to English sounds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Hawaiian_in_schools">Hawaiian in schools</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Hawaiian in schools">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Language_immersion#Hawaii" title="Language immersion">Language immersion § Hawaii</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hawaiian_medium_schools">Hawaiian medium schools</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawaiian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Hawaiian medium schools">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The Hawaiian medium education system is a combination of charter, public, and private schools.
